SPECIAL TERM JULY 1972
Special Term of Court called by Chief Justice (July 7, 1972)--
Brennan, J., absent but participated in cases (A-23, A-24, 72–
34, 72-35, A-1320) ----
Per curiam opinion on stays (A-23, A-24) (July 7, 1972) –
Stay entered by Court (A-1320) –
Page
1
1
1
1

FRIDAY, JULY 7, 1972
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
The Court met in Special Term pursuant to a call by the Chief
Justice.
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Mr. Justice Brennan was absent but, being unable to reach Wash-
ington in time for the Term, had stated his desire to participate on the
basis of review of all the files and records in the cases.
The Chief Justice declared the Special Term convened with the
concurrence of all Justices, to consider applications Nos. A-23 and
A-24 for the stays of the judgment of the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, and the petitions for
writs of certiorari to said Court of Appeals, No. 72-34, Lawrence F.
O'Brien et al. v. Willie Brown et al. and No. 72-35, Thomas E. Keane
et al. v. National Democratic Party et al.
By per curiam opinion the applications for stays of the judgment
of the Court of Appeals were granted. The action on the petitions for
writs of certiorari was deferred for consideration in due course when
responses have been filed. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice White
would deny the applications for stays of the judgment of the Court
of Appeals. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
No. A-1320. The Atchison. Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Com-
pany et al., applicants, v. The Wichita Board of Trade et al.
On consideration of the appellants' application for stay, the appel-
lees' reply to the application, and the affidavits and memoranda filed
in support of the application and reply, IT IS ORDERED:
(1) That, subject to the condition set forth in paragraph 2 herein,
the judgment of the United States District Court for the District of
Kansas entered in this matter on June 8, 1972, be and hereby is stayed
pending a final determination of the appeal by this Court.
(2) That, as a condition of the foregoing stay, each railroad collect-
ing in-transit grain inspection charges under the challenged tariffs
510-278-72—1

FRIDAY, JULY 7, 1972
2
shall immediately take steps, including publication of appropriate
provisions in applicable tariffs, to do the following:
(a) keep accurate accounts in detail of all amounts hereafter
received during the existence of the stay by reason of in-transit
grain inspection charges, specifying by whom and in whose behalf
such amounts are paid; and
(b) in the event the order suspending the charges is affirmed
by this Court, refund (with interest) of such amounts to persons
in whose behalf such amounts were paid, without the necessity
for such persons to make applications for refunds. In the event.
this Court's action should be other than in affirmance of the re-
sults reached by the district court, this Court may make such fur-
ther order concerning the disposition of the aforesaid amounts as
the Court may deem appropriate.
Adjourned to the time and place appointed by law.
☑

MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1972
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce that the 1972 Term of the Supreme
Court of the United States is now convened."
ADMISSION OF ATTORNEYS DURING THE SUMMER RECESS
The following attorneys were admitted to the Bar of this Court by
action of single Justices during the summer recess, pursuant to the
Order of this Court entered on the twenty-fourth day of May, 1971:

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1972
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
33
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-362. Peter Bridge, applicant, v. New Jersey. The application
for a stay presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to
the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant the stay.
Х
510-278-72——6

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1972
34
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-325. American Party of Texas et al., applicants, v. Bob
Bullock, Secretary of State of Texas. The application for a temporary
restraining order presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. A-370. Edgar D. Whitcomb et al., applicants, v. Communist
Party of Indiana et al. The motion of petitioners, Edgar D. Whitcomb
et al., for an emergency stay presented to Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and
by him referred to the Court, is denied as moot. The cross motion of
respondents, Communist Party of Indiana et al., to petition for a
mandate to enforce the prior order of the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Indiana is also denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas would treat the Communist Party's motion as a jurisdictional
statement and postpone the question of jurisdiction to the hearing
of the case on the merits.
510-278-72— -7

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1972
35
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-374. Bruce W. Pattani et al., applicants, v. David R. Meyers
et al. The application for a temporary restraining order presented
to Mr. Justice Brennan, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1972
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
36
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice.
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
JR
No. 70-5083. Sheila Newman, appellant, v. Tanas Newman. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Motion for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further consideration in light
of Boddie v. Connecticut, 401 U.S. 371 (1971).
No. 71-1027. Richard John Baker et al., appellants, v. Gerald R.
Nelson. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-1132. Mayor and City Council of Baltimore et al., appel-
lants, v. John E. Silver et ux. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 71–1445. Arlen Specter, etc., appellant, v. C. Delores Tucker,
Secretary of the Commonwealth, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-1530. Donald Retza, appellant, v. Raymond B. Fortune.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Cuyahoga County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-1681. Surety Savings & Loan Association, appellant, v.
Wisconsin Department of Transportation, Division of Highways. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-61. Snohomish County Board of Equalization et al., appel-
lants, v. Washington State Department of Revenue et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-88. Mesa Verde Company, appellant, v. The Board of
County Commissioners of the County of Montezuma et al. Appeal
510-278-72-9

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1972
37
from the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-91. Sheldon Davis, appellant, v. New York. Appeal from
the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, First
Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
5045
No. 72- Donald Crawford, appellant, v. Missouri. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-1109. Alan E. Norris et al., appellants, v. Samuel J. Jordan
et al.; and
No. 71-1439. Alan E. Norris et al., appellants, v. Samuel J. Jordan
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Ohio. Motion to defer consideration denied. The appeals
are dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 71-1186. Fry's Food Stores, Inc. and Charles L. Fry, appel-
lants, v. California. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California.
The appeal is dismissed.
No. 71-1233. William Bridgeforth, appellant, v. Illinois; and
No. 71-6422. Willie Davis, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeals from
the Supreme Court of Illinois. Motions to dispense with printing
jurisdictional statement and to dispense with printing motion to
dismiss in No. 71–1233 granted. Motion to supplement jurisdictional
statement in No. 71-6422 granted. The appeals are dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
probable jurisdiction and set cases for oral argument.
No. 71-1235. Clifton M. Craig et al., appellants, v. Beaty Mae
Gilliard et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of North Carolina. Motion to dispense with print-
ing motion to affirm granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71–1363. Edward M. Davis, Chief of Police for the City of
Los Angeles, et al.; appellants, v. Cinema Classics Ltd., Inc., et
al.; and

Court for the Central District of California. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Stewart would note probable jurisdiction and set cases for oral
argument.

from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for

CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-1302. Superintendent of Field Unit No. 9, petitioner, v.
Lewis E. Terry. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of respondent
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certi-
orari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further consideration in light of Colten v. Kentucky,
407 U.S. 104 (1972).
No. 71-1548. In the Matter of the Imprisonment of Edward Leary,
Jr., petitioner. On petition for writ of certiorari to the General Court
of Justice of North Carolina, Superior Court Division. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to
the General Court of Justice of North Carolina, Superior Court Divi-
sion, for further consideration in light of Jackson v. Indiana, 406
U.S. 715 (1972). Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from vacating and re-
manding this case.
No. 71-6460. William Gause, petitioner, v. Arizona. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1972
42
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Arizona for further consideration in light of Stewart v. Massa-
chusetts, 408 U.S. 845 (1972).
No. 71–6570. Einer Ketola, petitioner, v. United States. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon the representations of the
Solicitor General set forth in his memorandum for the United States
filed June 16, 1972, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of the position pres-
ently asserted by the Government. Application for bail denied with-
out prejudice to renewal of application to the Court of Appeals.
No. 71-6773. Karen Duncan, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of
Gelbard v. United States, 408 U.S. 41 (1972).
No. 72-5009. Nancy Barlow Webb, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further considera-
tion in light of Gelbard v. United States, 408 U.S. 41 (1972).
No. 72-28. Northern States Power Company, petitioner, v. Robert
J. Ihrke and Mary E. Ihrke. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals with instructions to dismiss case as moot.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 72-34. Lawrence F. O'Brien et al., petitioners, v. Willie
Brown et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Motions to dis-
pense with printing petition and to print respondents' brief granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals with directions to dismiss case as
moot.
No. 72-35. Thomas E. Keane et al., petitioners, v. National Demo-
cratic Party et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Motions
to dispense with printing petition and to print respondents' brief
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1972
43
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals to determine whether
this case has become moot.
No. 72-5110. Maria Refugio Martinez-Frausto, petitioner, v.
United States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon
the representations of the Solicitor General set forth in his memo-
randum for the United States filed September 6, 1972, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further con-
sideration in light of the position presently asserted by the Govern-
ment.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1165. October Term, 1971. In Matter of Disbarment of
William M. Morton, Jr. It having been reported to this Court that
William M. Morton, Jr., of St. Joseph, Missouri, has been disbarred
from the practice of law in all of the courts of the State of Missouri,
and this Court by order of May 15, 1972, having suspended the
said William M. Morton, Jr., from the practice of law in this Court
and directed that a rule issue requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred.
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon
the respondent and that the time within which to file a return has
expired;
It is ordered that the said William M. Morton, Jr., be, and he is
hereby, disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his
name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice
before the Bar of this Court.
No. A-271. Non-Resident Taxpayers Association of Pennsylvania
and New Jersey, et al., applicants v. Charles Murray et al. The appli-
cation for an injunction presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant
the application.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff v. State of Louisiana. The
Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master are set for oral argu-
ment in due course.
No. 56, Original. Commonwealth of Virginia, individually and on
behalf of all other states similarly situated, plaintiff, v. International
Air Transport Association et al. The motion of the Metropolitan
Washington Board of Trade for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
is granted. The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is denied.
Washington v. General Motors Corporation, 406 U.S. 109 (1972).
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions.

and Phillips Petroleum Company. The motion of the Solicitor General

on behalf of the United States is granted.

petitioner v. Gary R. Benson and Arthur C. Tabbot. The motion of
the Association of Data Processing Service Organizations, Software
Products and Service Section, for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment, as amicus curiae, is denied. Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion.
No. 71-507. Wilfred Keyes et al., petitioners, v. School District
No. 1, Denver, Colorado, et al. The joint motion for additional time
for oral argument is granted and fifteen minutes are allotted for that
purpose to each side. Mr. Justice White took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this motion.
No. 71-575. Linda Gomez, individually and as next friend of Zo-
raida Gomez, appellant, v. Francisco Ocasio Perez. The motion of
appellant to dispense with printing the appendix and to proceed on
the original record is granted. The motion of the American Civil
Liberties Union for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 71-651. California, petitioner, v. Judith Krivda and Roger T.
Minor. The motion to permit showing of a motion picture during
oral argument, to permit two counsel to argue orally and for addi-
tional time for oral argument is denied. The motion of the National
Legal Aid and Defender Association for leave to dispense with print-
ing amicus curiae brief is granted.

Parts Co., et al.; and
No. 71-691. Edward J. Barrett, County Clerk of Cook County,
Illinois, et al., petitioners, v. Clemens K. Shapiro et al. The motion of

Corporate Fiduciaries Association of Illinois, for leave to file a brief,
as amici curiae, is granted. The motion of Proviso Township High
School District #209 et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is
granted, but the motion to participate in oral argument, as amici
curiae, is denied. The motion of Charles Marshall, State's Attorney,
County of DeKalb, Illinois, for leave to intervene in No. 71-685, is
denied.
No. 71–829. Leila Mourning, petitioner, v. Family Publications
Service, Inc. The motion of The National Consumer Law Center, Inc.,
for leave to dispense with printing amicus curiae brief is granted.
The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, in support of petitioner is granted and 15
minutes are allotted for that purpose. The respondent is also allotted
15 additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 71-834. Rosalind McClanahan, etc., appellant, v. State Tax
Commission of Arizona. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave
to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, in support of the
appellant is granted and 15 minutes are allotted for that purpose. The
appellee is allotted 15 additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 71-863. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., petitioner, v.
Democratic National Committee;
No. 71-864. Federal Communications Commission et al., peti-
tioners, v. Business Executives' Move for Vietnam Peace et al.;
No. 71-865. Post-Newsweek Stations, Capital Area, Inc., peti-
tioner, v. Business Executives' Move for Vietnam Peace; and
No. 71-866. American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., petitioner,
v. Democratic National Committee. The motion of Columbia Broad-
casting System, Inc., and Post-Newsweek Stations, Capital Area, Inc.,
for additional time for oral argument is granted and 712 minutes are
allotted to the petitioners for that purpose. The respondents are also
allotted 71/2 additional minutes for oral argument.

States. The motion of appellant for additional time for oral argument
is denied. The motion of the Federal Power Commission for leave
to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied. Mr.
Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision or these motions.

ney General of the United States. The application for a stay pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by him referred to the Court,
is granted. Should the petition for writ of certiorari be denied, this
stay is to terminate automatically. Should the petition for writ of
certiorari be granted, this stay is to remain in effect pending the
sending down of the judgment of this Court.

No. 71-6305. Steven C. Rettig, petitioner, v. Illinois. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari and reverse
judgment of Supreme Court of Illinois. Turner v. Louisiana, 379 U.S.
466 (1965) and Gonzales v. Beto, 405 U.S. 1052 (1972). Mr. Justice
Blackmun would grant certiorari, vacate judgment and remand case
to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Turner v. Louisiana, 379 U.S. 466
(1965) and Gonzales v. Beto, 405 U.S. 1052 (1972).

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1972
96
No. 71-6467. James E. Thomas, petitioner, v. California. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First
Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Marshall would grant cer-
tiorari.
No. 71-6528. James Patrick Morningstar, petitioner, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari,
vacate judgment, and remand case to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in light of the memorandum of the Solicitor General
filed June 7, 1972, stating that the pre-jeopardy dismissal of the
indictment was appealable not to the Court of Appeals, but directly
to this Court. See United States v. International Minerals & Chemical
Corp., 402 U.S. 558 (1971) and United States v. Fabrizio, 385 U.S. 263
(1966).
No. 71-6536. Earl Guy, petitioner, v. United States. Motion to
recuse, presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist,
is by them severally denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied.

No. 69–5031. Elmer Branch, petitioner, v. Texas. Motion of the
Committee of State Chief Justices (Retired) for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, in Nos. 69-5003, 69–5030 and 69-5031 in support of
rehearing granted. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 70-5039. Margarita Fuentes et al., appellants, v. Robert L.
Shevin, Attorney General of Florida et al. Motion of the National Con-
sumer Law Center, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in
opposition to the petitions for rehearing denied. Petitions for rehear-
ing denied. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part
in the consideration or decision of these petitions and motion.
No. 70-5138. Paul Parham et al., appellants, v. Americo V. Cor-
tese et al. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 71–288. Melvin R. Laird, Secretary of Defense, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Arlo Tatum et al. Motion to withdraw the opinion of this
Court denied. Motion to recuse, nunc pro tunc, presented to Mr. Justice
Rehnquist, is by him denied. Petition for rehearing denied.
No. 71-315. Deepsouth Packing Co., Inc., petitioner, v. The Lait-
ram Corporation. Motion for leave to supplement petition for rebear-
ing granted. Petition for rehearing denied.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1972
102
No. 71–573. Melvin Laird, Secretary of Defense, et al., petitioners,
v. Jim Nick Nelms et al. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 71–1017. Mike Gravel, United States Senator, petitioner, v.
United States; and
No. 71-1026. United States, petitioner, v. Mike Gravel, United
States Senator. Motion to recuse, presented to Mr. Justice Rehnquist,
is by him denied. Petition for rehearing denied.
No. 71–1169. Mobil Oil Corporation, petitioner, v. Carl F. Matzen
et al.;
No. 71–1179. Amoco Production Company, petitioner, v. Leland C.
Waechter et al.;
No. 71-1188. Cities Service Oil Company, petitioner, v. Carl F.
Matzen et al.; and
No. 71-1326. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Mobil Oil
Corporation et al. Petitions for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Stewart
and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
these petitions.
No. 71–1232. Herman Landerman et al., petitioners, v. Commis-
sioner of Internal Revenue. Motion to dispense with printing petition
for rehearing granted. Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing
denied.
No. 71-1291. Stephen S. Chandler, petitioner, v. Frank J. Bat-
tisti, Chief Judge, United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Ohio. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 71–1411. Lawrence Lii, petitioner, v. Sida of Hawaii. Inc.,
et al. Motion to dispense with printing petition for rehearing granted.
Petition for rehearing denied.
No. 71-1435. The State Department of Health and Rehabilita-
tive Services, et al., appellants, v. Antonio Zarate, etc., et al. Petition
for rehearing or in the alternative for clarification of lower court
opinion denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit beginning
December 4, 1972, and ending December 8, 1972, and for such
further time as may be required to complete unfinished business,
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes
of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 71-36. California et al., appellants, v. Robert LaRue et al.
Argued by Mr. L. Stephen Porter for the appellants and by Mr.
Harrison W. Hertzberg and Mr. Kenneth Philip Scholtz for the
appellees.
No. 71-651. California, petitioner, v. Judith Krivda and Roger
T. Minor. Argued by Mr. Russell Iungerich for the petitioner and
by Mr. Roger S. Hanson for the respondents.
No. 71-732. Merle R. Schneckloth, Superintendent, California
Conservation Center, petitioner, v. Robert Clyde Bustamonte. Argued
by Mr. Robert R. Granucci for the petitioner and by Mr. Stuart P.
Tobisman for the respondent, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court.
No. 71–827. Hughes Tool Company et al., petitioners, v. Trans
World Airlines, Inc.; and
No. 71–830. Trans World Airlines, Inc., petitioner, v. Hughes
Tool Company et al. Argued by Mr. Charles Alan Wright for Hughes
Tool Company et al. and by Mr. Dudley B. Tenney for Trans World
Airlines, Inc.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1972

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 70-18. Jane Roe et al, appellants, v. Henry Wade, Reargued
by Mrs. Sarah R. Weddington for the appellants and by Mr. Robert
C. Flowers for the appellee.
No. 70-40. Mary Doe et al., appellants, v. Arthur K. Bolton, as
Attorney General of the State of Georgia, et al. Reargued by Mrs.
Margie Pitts Hames for the appellants and by Mrs. Dorothy T.
Beasley for the appellees.
No. 71-224. Harold R. Swenson, Warden, petitioner, v. James
William Stidham. Argued by Mr. Kenneth M. Romines for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. Mark M. Hennelly for the respondent.
No. 71-366. Tidewater Oil Company, petitioner, v. United States
and Phillips Petroleum Company. Argued by Mr. Moses Lasky for
the petitioner and by Mr. A. Raymond Randolph Jr., for the respond-
ents, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1972
114
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

Harsha, Jr.

Washington, D.C.

William Alfred Hillhouse, II Denver, Colo.

Halvorson, Jr.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Justice Marshall will not be present today but will participate
in the cases to be argued on the basis of the entire record, briefs, and
the tape recording of the oral arguments."
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 71-507. Wilfred Keyes et al., petitioners, v. School District
No. 1, Denver, Colorado, et al. One and one half hours allowed for
oral orgument. Argued by Mr. James M. Nabrit, III, and Mr. Gordon
C. Greiner for the petitioners and by Mr. William K. Ris for the
respondents.
No. 71-1332. San Antonio Independent School District et al., ap-
pellants, v. Demetrio P. Rodriguez et al. Argued by Mr. Charles
Alan Wright for the appellants and by Mr. Arthur Gochman for the
appellees.
No. 71-895. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. In-
ternational Van Lines. Argued by Mr. Peter G. Nash for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. Norman H. Kirshman for the respondent.
Adjourned until Monday, October 16, 1972, at 10 o'clock

510-278-72- -20

MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1972
115
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and
Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-1408. Aero Mayflower Transit Company, Inc., et al., ap-
pellants, v. United States et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Indiana; and
No. 71-1419. John A. Hutter et ux., appellants, v. Bernard J.
Korzen, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. Motion for
leave to supplement jurisdictional statement in No. 71-1408 granted.
The appeals are dismissed for failure to docket cases within the time
prescribed by Rule 13(1) of the Rules of this Court. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 71–1447. Rita C. Davidson, Secretary, Maryland Department
of Employment and Social Services, et al., appellants, v. Robert Fran-
cis, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Maryland. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-1547. C & H Transportation Co., Inc., et al., appellants, v.
Interstate Commerce Commission; and
No. 72-149. United States, Appellant, v. Interstate Commerce
Commission (International Transport, Inc., case). Appeals from the
United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri.
Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-6774. Robert H. Simpson, appellant, v. Guy R. Oates et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of California. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-1554. United States Chamber of Commerce, appellant, v.
Robert Francis etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Maryland. Motion of appellee Wright for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Motion for consolidation
with No. 71–1447 and for other relief denied. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction.
No. 71-6740. Shirley J. Lloyd et al., appellants, v. Third Judicial
District Court in and for Salt Lake County, Utah. Appeal from the
510-278-72—
21

MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1972
116
Supreme Court of Utah. The appeal is dismissed it appearing that the
judgment below rests upon an adequate state ground.
No. 72-25. American Yearbook Company, Inc., appellant, v. Reu-
ben O'D. Askew et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Middle District of Florida. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice White would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 72-150. United States, appellant, v. Interstate Commerce
Commission (Ace Doran Hauling Co. case). Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
No. 72-189. Robert Kisley, etc., appellant, v. The City of Falls
Church, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-5252. Carolyn G. Howard, appellant, v. Donald L. Allen.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-5161. Dominick Saffioti, appellant, v. United States Gov-
ernment. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-5294. Johnson Hill and Dwight Springs, appellants, v.
Illinois. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-5026. William Noel Gaglie, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration
in light of the position presently asserted by the Government.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-349. Samuel C. Stone et al., applicants, v. Maine. The ap-
plication for bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him re-
ferred to the Court is denied.
No. A-360. Arnold Markle et al., applicants, v. Janice Abele et al.
The application for stay presented to the Chief Justice, and by him

MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1972
117
referred to the Court, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas would deny
the application.
No. A-377. Board of Education of Memphis City Schools et al.,
applicants, v. Deborah A. Northcross et al. The application for
stay presented to Mr. Justice Stewart, and by him referred to the
Court, is denied.
No. A-393. John B. Slobodian, applicant, v. New Jersey. The ap-
plication for bail presented to Mr. Justice Brennan, and by him re-
ferred to the Court, is denied.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The motion of the State of Louisiana for entry of a
supplemental decree as to the United States (No. 4) is granted. The
motion of the United States for leave to file an account of funds
released from impoundment pursuant to the supplemental decree
(No. 3) of December 20, 1971, is granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took
no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 58, Original. The American Party et al., plaintiffs, v. State of
New York et al. The motion for a temporary restraining order is
denied.
No. 70-2. United States, appellant, v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Super
8mm. Film, et al. The motion of the First Amendment Lawyers'
Association for leave to file an untimely brief, as amicus curiae in
support of the appellant is granted. The motion of Joel Hirschhorn
for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, in support
of appellant is denied.
No. 70-40. Mary Doe et al., appellants, v. Arthur K. Bolton, as
Attorney General of the State of Georgia, et al. The motion of
appellants for leave to present late authorities is granted.
No. 71-653. Thomas S. Gibson et al., appellants, v. L. M. Berryhill
et al. The motion to dispense with printing the appendix is granted.
No. 71-718. Paul D. McGinnis, Commissioner of Correction, State
of New York, et al., appellants, v. James Royster et al. The motion
to permit G. Jeffrey Sorge, Esquire, to argue, pro hac vice, in place
of James J. McDonough for appellees is granted.
No. 71–1134. Harry Roaden, petitioner, v. Kentucky. The motion
of Charles H. Keating, Jr., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
is granted. The motion of the First Amendment Lawyers' Associ-
ation for leave to file an untimely brief, as amicus curiae, in support
of petitioner is denied. The motion of Joel Hirschhorn for leave to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, in support of petitioner
is denied.
No. 71-1136. Murray Tillman et al., petitioners, v. Wheaton-
Haven Recreation Association, Inc., et al. The motion of respondent

MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1972
118
McIntyre for additional counsel to participate in oral argument is
granted, but the motion for additional time for oral argument is
denied.
No. 71-1192. Donald Goldstein, Ruth Koven and Donald Koven,
petitioners, v. California. The motion of American Federation of
Musicians et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
The motion of Recording Industry Association of America, Inc., for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 71-1315. Howard Alexander et al., petitioners, v. Virginia.
The motion of The First Amendment Lawyers' Association for leave
to file an untimely brief, as amicus curiae, in support of petitioners is
granted. The motion of Joel Hirschhorn for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, in support of petitioners is denied.
No. 72-492. Zali Fried, petitioner, v. United States. The appli-
cation for continuance of bail and stay of mandate presented to Mr.
Justice Marshall, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 72-549. School Board of the City of Richmond, Virginia,
et al., petitioners, v. State Board of Education of the Commonwealth
of Virginia et al. The motion to advance and for pendente lite relief
is denied.
No. 72-5038. Elizabeth Chavez et al., petitioners, v. Freshpict
Foods, Inc., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief ex-
pressing the views of the United States.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 71-1523. Richard W. Hunt, appellant, v. Robert E. McNair,
Governor of South Carolina, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of South Carolina. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
No. 72-75. Georgia et al., appellants, v. United States. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 71-1583. Edmund G. Brown, Jr., Secretary of State of Cali-
fornia, appellant, v. Raymond G. Chote Motion of appellee for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted.

Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
would grant certiorari.
No. 71-6869. Robert Dorado, etc., petitioner, v. Henry W. Kerr,
Chairman, California Adult Authority, etc. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 72-64. Charles J. DeMoulin et al., petitioners, v. City and
County of Denver et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Colorado denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 72-81. Veterans and Reservists for Peace in Vietnam, peti-
tioner, v. Regional Commissioner of Customs, Region II, et al. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 72-145. David Noland et al., petitioners, v. William R. Deso-
bry, Commanding General, United States Army Armor Center, Fort
Knox, Kentucky. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
would grant certiorari.
No. 72-146. Bill R. Hunter, dba The Courier, petitioner v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would
grant certiorari.
No. 72-198. Morton International, Inc., petitioner, v. Southern
Pacific Transportation Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Utah. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 71-6489. James McLamore, petitioner, v. South Carolina
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South
Carolina denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
510-278-72-22

MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1972
126
No. 71-6888. George Hadley, petitioner, v. Alabama. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama denied. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72-53. Michael Edward Francis, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. 72-96. Memphis Light, Gas and Water Division, petitioner,
v. Federal Power Commission et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.
No. 72–105. Capital Assistance Corporation, petitioner, v. United
States et al. Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 72–151. C. Murray Henderson, Warden, petitioner, v. Robert
Favre. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun would
grant certiorari.
No. 72-204. B. G. Solomon, petitioner, v. Seaboard Coast Line
Railroad Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Virginia denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 72-207. Marvin R. Cole et al., petitioners, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 72-5238. Robert Charles Kochel, petitioner, v. Maryland. Mo-
tion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, October 24, 1972, until
Monday, November 6, 1972.

510-278-72–27

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1972
136
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 57, Original. State of Illinois, plaintiff, v. State of Michigan.
The motions of Jack Federoff and William F. Ewing, dba William
Ewing Roofing Company; and John H. Shannon, for leave to file
briefs, as amicus curiae, are granted. The motion of the State of Illinois
for leave to file a bill of complaint is denied. Opinion per curiam.
No. 71-6918. Woodie Robinson, appellant, v. Edward V. Hanra-
han, States Attorney of Cook County. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Illinois. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted,
judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Illi-
nois for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-15. Helen Marcia Sweetenham et al., appellants, v. John
J. Gilligan, Governor of the State of Ohio, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 70-48. Don B. Pratt and Luther J. Wilson, appellants, v.
Leila Begley, Secretary of State of Kentucky, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set case for
oral argument.
No. 71-1625. Mark Richard Kirstel, appellant, v. Maryland. Ap-
peal from the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. The appeal
510-278-72-28

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1972
137
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 71-1668. Gurthie A. Mayes and Charles G. Garner, appellants,
v. Frederick S. Ellis et al.; and
No. 71-1684. Edith Hill et al., appellants, v. John J. McKeithen
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would
note probable jurisdiction and set cases for oral argument.
No. 71-6627. Yvonne Martin, appellant, v. City of New Orleans.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further consideration
in light of Gooding v. Wilson, 405 U.S. 518 (1972). See Lewis v.
City of New Orleans, 408 U.S. 913 (1972). The Chief Justice, Mr.
Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissent for the reasons
expressed in the several opinions in Rosenfeld v. New Jersey, 408 U.S.
901 (1972); Lewis v. City of New Orleans, 408 U.S. 913 (1972); and
Brown v. Oklahoma, 408 U.S. 914 (1972). Mr. Justice Powell would
remand the cause for further consideration only in light of Chaplin-
sky v. New Hampshire, 315 U.S. 568 (1942). (See concurring opinion
in Lewis v. City of New Orleans, 408 U.S. 913).
No. 72-12. Mabel S. Amos, Secretary of State of Alabama, et al.,
appellants, v. M. O. Sims et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Middle District of Alabama. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-44. Douglas B. Fugate, State Highway Commissioner of
Virginia, appellant, v. Potomac Electric Power Company and Wash-
ington Gas Light Company. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Virginia. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 72-180. National Small Shipments Traffic Conference, Inc.,
et al., appellants, v. Ringsby Truck Lines, Inc., et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Colorado. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 72-232. Borough of East Rutherford et al., appellants, v.
New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 72–234. H. F. Thompson et al., appellants, v. Kansas City
Power & Light Company. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1972
138
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdic-
tion and set case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-216. Jeffrey H. Smilow, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. On the representation of the Solicitor General
set forth in his memorandum for the United States, filed September 28,
1972, petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of the position presently asserted by the Government.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-263. Oxnard School District Board of Trustees et al., ap-
plicants, v. Debbie and Doreen Soria et al. The application for stay
presented to Mr. Justice Powell, and by him referred to the Court, is
denied.
No. 71-485. Robert Gottschalk, Acting Commissioner of Patents,
petitioner, v. Gary R. Benson and Arthur C. Tabbot. The motion of
Computer Software Analysts, Inc., and Computerized Lists Corp., for
leave to file an untimely brief, as amici curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 71–1051. Paris Adult Theatre I et al., petitioners, v. Lewis R.
Slaton, District Attorney, Atlanta Judicial Circuit, et al. The motion
of Charles H. Keating, Jr., for leave to file an untimely brief, as amicus
curiae, in support of respondent is granted.
No. 71–1082. Reubin O'D. Askew et al., appellants, v. The Ameri-
can Waterways Operators, Inc., et al. The motion of The American Bar
Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 71-1119. Indiana Employment Security Division et al., ap-
pellants, v. Essie D. Burney. The motion of National Employment Law
Project et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. The
motion of American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial
Organizations for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 71-1178. Gulf States Utilities Company, petitioner, v. Federal
Power Commission et al. The motion of the American Public Power
Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 71–1193. United States, appellant, v. Travis Paul Enmons
et al. The motion of American Newspaper Publishers Association
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1972
139
No. 71-1585. United States, petitioner, v. Richard Russell. The
motion for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered
that Thomas H. S. Brucker, Esquire, of Seattle, Washington, be, and
he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this
case.
No. 72-243. Clean Air Coordinating Committee, petitioner, v.
Roth Adam Fuel Company et al. The Solicitor General is invited to
file a brief expressing the views of the United States.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 71-1623. Bob Bullock, etc., appellant, v. Dan Weiser et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Texas. Motion to dispense with printing motion to dismiss
or affirm granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
