SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
OPINIONS
No. 71–889. Lillian V. Couch, petitioner, v. United States and
Edward F. Jennings, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall.
No. 71-858. Thomas Ricci, petitioner, v. Chicago Mercantile Ex-
change et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Stewart,
and Mr. Justice Powell join.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 71-1336. In re Application of Fre Le Poole Griffiths for Ad-
mission to the Bar, appellant. Argued by Mr. R. David Broiles for
the appellant and by Mr. George R. Tiernan for the appellee.
No. 71–6060. Anthony Louis Tacon, petitioner, v. Arizona. Argued
by Mr. Robert J. Hirsh for the petitioner and by Mr. William P.
Dixon for the respondent.
No. 71-1225. John R. Gagnon, Warden, petitioner, v. Gerald H.
Scarpelli. Argued by Mr. William A. Platz for the petitioner and by
Mr. William M. Coffey for the respondent.
No. 71–1369. Russell G. Oswald, Commissioner of Correctional
Services, et al., petitioners, v. Eugene Rodriguez et al. Argued by Mrs.
Lillian Z. Cohen for the petitioners and by Mr. Herman Schwartz
for the respondents.
No. 71-653. Thomas S. Gibson et al., appellants, v. L. M. Berry-
hill et al. Argument commenced by Mr. Richard A. Billups, Jr., for
the appellants.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

OPINIONS
No. 71–749. United States, appellant, v. Robert William Kras.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of New York. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of New York for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr.
Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 71-564. District of Columbia, petitioner, v. Melvin Carter.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 71–827. Hughes Tool Company et al., petitioners, v. Trans
World Airlines, Inc.; and
No. 71–830. Trans World Airlines, Inc., petitioner, v. Hughes
Tool Company et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment in 71-827 reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Writ dismissed in No. 71–830.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 71-5656. Doris Philpott and William Wilkes, petitioners, v.
Essex County Welfare Board. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of New Jersey. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of New Jersey for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals

MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1973
342
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice

OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 72–603. Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion and Welfare, appellant, v. Deborah Morris et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.
motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma papueris granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Georgia for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
No. 72-691. American Trial Lawyers Association, New Jersey
Branch, et al. appellants, v. New Jersey Supreme Court. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of New Jersey for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–446. Franz Joseph Tomasino, appellant, v. California. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereupon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-833. William E. Goetz & Sons et al., appellants, v. Board
of Regents, State Senior Colleges, et al. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 72-5612. Karen Bodisco, etc., appellant, v. Richard Nixon,
President of the United States, et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
510-278-73-68

MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1973
343
No. 72-537. Raymond D. Georges et al., appellants, v. Eva M.
McClellan and Berta Phillips. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Rhode Island. Motion of appellees for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Motion of Rhode Island
Consumers' Council for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
Judgments affirmed.
No. 72-669. Smith's Transfer Corporation, appellant, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of Virginia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would note probable jurisdiction and set
case for oral argument.
No. 72–687. McLean Trucking Company, appellant, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Middle District of North Carolina. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
No. 72-749. Sunset Amusement Co. et al., appellants, v. Board of
Police Commissioners of the City of Los Angeles. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 72-5471. Lawrence Fuchs, appellant, v. Dorn Silvester. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-5293. Albert H. Carter, petitioner, v. United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to file petition for
writ of mandamus denied. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Treating the papers submitted as a petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit, certiorari granted and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further consideration in light of the memorandum for
respondent filed by the Solicitor General in this Court on Decem-
ber 19, 1972.
No. 72-5391. D. W. Jackson, petitioner, v. Georgia. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death
penalty imposed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Geor-
gia for further consideration in light of Stewart v. Massachusetts,
408 U.S. 845 (1972).

MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1973
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
344
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New York, et al. The supplemental report of the Special
Master is received and ordered filed. Exceptions, with supporting
briefs, may be filed within thirty days.
No. 70–35. T. Edward Austin, etc., et al., appellants, v. Russ Meyer
et al. The motion of appellants to reinstate the stay heretofore vacated
by order of this Court on June 26, 1972, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No.71-1031. Leonard Tonasket, appellant, v. Washington et al.
The motion of appellant for order requiring briefs upon the issue of
jurisdiction is denied.
No. 71–1553. John J. Gilligan, Governor of Ohio, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Craig Morgan et al. The motion of the Law Revision
Center for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 71-1694. Sharron A. Frontiero and Joseph Frontiero, appel-
lants, v. Melvin R. Laird, Secretary of Defense, et al. The motion of
appellants to divide oral argument is granted.
No. 71-6732. James Chaffin, petitioner, v. LeRoy Stynchcombe,
Sheriff of Fulton County. The motion of petitioner for the appoint-
ment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Glenn Zell, Esquire,
of Atlanta, Georgia, a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is
hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 72-5410. Richard Black, petitioner, v. United States. The re-
spondent is requested to file a response to the motion for leave to file
petition for rehearing within thirty days.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 72–792. New York State Department of Social Services et al.,
appellants, v. Dolores Dublino et al., and
No. 72-802. Onondaga County Department of Social Services et
al., appellants, v. Dolores Dublino et al. Appeals from the United
States District Court for the Western District of New York. Motion
of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In these
cases further consideration of the question of jurisdiction postponed
to the hearing of the cases on the merits. Cases consolidated and a total
of one hour allotted for oral argument.

First Appellate District, granted.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Customs and Patent Appeals for the period January 8 and 9, 1973,
and for such further time as may be required to complete unfinished
business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, January 22, 1973, until
Tuesday February 20, 1973.

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, and
Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 71-6272. Samuel Ed Robinson, petitioner, v. William S. Neil,
Warden. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals so that respondent may have an opportunity to
present this issue there or in the District Court. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 71-951. Almota Farmers Elevator and Warehouse Company,
petitioner, v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.

trict. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Civil
Appeals of Texas, Fourth Supreme Judicial District, for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist
joins. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.

case remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Indiana to consider whether the case has become moot. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Bren-
nan joins. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.

(JOURNAL)
SATURDAY, JANUARY 20, 1973
361
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Court convened and the Chief Justice announced that the Court
will take a recess to attend the inauguration of the President of the
United States.
The oath of office was administered to the Honorable Richard
Milhous Nixon as President of the United States by the Chief Justice.
The Clerk adjourned the Court until Monday, January 22, 1973, at
10 o'clock.

MONDAY, JANUARY 22, 1973
362
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 72-438. United States, petitioner, v. Edward G. Chandler and
Esther F. Born, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ
of certiorari granted, judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-524. Maryland People's Party et al., appellants, v. Marvin
Mandel, Governor of the State of Maryland, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Maryland. Judgment
affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan would dismiss the appeal as moot.
No. 72-638. Lake Charles American Press, appellant, v. Earnest
Francis. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Douglas would postpone the question of jurisdiction to a hearing of
the case on the merits. Mr. Justice Brennan would dismiss the appeal
for want of jurisdiction being of the view that the decision of the
Louisiana Supreme Court was based on an adequate state ground.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-5119. James Ross, Jr., petitioner, v. Massachusetts. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massa-
chusetts. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts for further considera-
tion in light of Ham v. South Carolina, U.S. ——— (1973).
–
510-278-73-73

MONDAY, JANUARY 22, 1973
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
363
No. 59, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. States of
Nevada and California. The motion of Association on American
Indian Affairs, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in sup-
port of the motion for leave to file bill of complaint, is granted. The
motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is set for oral argument
in due course.
No. A-570. Carl Wayne Fuller, applicant, v. Michigan; and
No. A-634. Michael Marion et al., applicants, v. United States. The
applications for bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him
referred to the Court, are denied.
No. A-674. B.P.O.E. Lodge No. 2043 of Brunswick et al., ap-
plicants v. Keith Ingraham et al. The application for a stay of the
mandate of the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine presented to Mr.
Justice Rehnquist, and by him referred to the Court, is granted.
No. A-740. James Grit et al., applicants, v. Benson A. Wolman et al.
The application for a stay of the judgment of the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Ohio presented to Mr. Justice
Stewart, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-762. Maurice Sigler, Chairman of the Board of Parole,
United States Department of Justice, et al., applicants, v. Phillip
Berrigan et al. The application for stay, presented to the Chief Jus-
tice, and by him referred to the Court, is granted. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 71–224. Harold R. Swenson, Warden, petitioner, v. James
William Stidham. The motion of the respondent to modify this
Court's opinion is hereby granted. The penultimate paragraph of the
opinion is amended by striking the sentence reading-"Neither the
District Court nor the Court of Appeals reached this issue." and
substituting therefor the following: "The Court of Appeals did not
reach this issue."
No. 72-147. Bob Bullock et al., appellants, v. Diana Regester et al.
The motion of appellees for additional time and for permission for
more than one counsel to argue is granted. Fifteen additional minutes
are allotted to both the appellees and the appellants for that purpose.
No. 72-214. The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Com-
pany, et al., appellants, v. The Wichita Board of Trade et al.; and
No. 72-433. Interstate Commerce Commission, appellant, v.
Wichita Board of Trade. The motion of appellants for additional
time for oral argument and for two counsel to argue is granted. Five
additional minutes are allotted to both the appellants and the appellees
for that purpose.

granted.
No. D-3. In Matter of the Disbarment of Sidney Konigsberg. It
having been reported to this Court that Sidney Konigsberg of New
York, New York, has been disbarred from the practice of law in all
the Courts of the State of New York, and this Court by order of No-
vember 6, 1972, having suspended the said Sidney Konigsberg from
the practice of law in this Court and directed that a rule issue requir-
ing him to show cause why he should not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon
the respondent and that the time within which to file a return has
expired;
It is ordered that the said Sidney Konigsberg be, and he is hereby,
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court.
No. D–6. In Matter of the Disbarment of Daniel D. Yudow. It
having been reported to this Court that Daniel D. Yudow of New
York, New York, has been disbarred from the practice of law in all
of the Courts of the State of New York and this Court by order of
November 6, 1972, having suspended the said Daniel D. Yudow from
the practice of law in this Court and directed that a rule issue requir-
ing him to show cause why he should not be disbarred;

MONDAY, JANUARY 22, 1973
365
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served
upon the respondent and that the time within which to file a return
has expired;
It is ordered that the said Daniel D. Yudow be, and he is hereby,
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court.
No. D-7. In Matter of the Disbarment of Benjamin B. Scherman.
It having been reported to this Court that Benjamin B. Scherman
of New York, New York, has been disbarred from the practice of law
in all of the Courts of the State of New York and this Court by order
of November 6, 1972, having suspended the said Benjamin B. Scher-
man from the practice of law in this Court and directed that a rule
issue requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served
upon the respondent and that the time within which to file a return
has expired;
It is ordered that the said Benjamin B. Scherman be, and he is
hereby, disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his
name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice be-
fore the Bar of this Court.

372
No. 72-758. United Transportation Union, petitioner v. Chicago &
North Western Railway Company; and
No. 72-789. United Transportation Union, petitioner, v. Chicago
& North Western Railway Company. Petitions for writs of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan would grant
certiorari.
No. 72-5773. Harvey A. Marcelin, petitioner. v. Vincent R. Man-
cusi, Superintendent, Attica Correctional Facility. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari because on
reading the record and Judge Kaufman's dissent in the Court of
Appeals, 462 F.3d 16, he believes a substantial question is raised
whether petitioner had effective assistance of counsel in the trial
for murder. Cf. Ellis v. United States, 356 U.S. 674, 675.

OPINIONS
378
No. 70-279. United States et al., appellants. v. Florida East Coast
Railway Company et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Middle District of Florida. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Florida so that it may consider those contentions of the
parties which are not disposed of by the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Stewart concurs. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70–18. Jane Roe et al., appellants, v. Henry Wade. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Texas. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part, and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Texas for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger in this case and in No. 70-40, post. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas in this case and in No. 70-40,
post. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins in this
case and in No. 70-40, post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
No. 70-40. Mary Doe et al., appellants, v. Arthur K. Bolton, as
Attorney General of the State of Georgia, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.
Judgment modified and as modified, affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger in this
case and in No. 70-18, ante. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas in this case and in No. 70-18, ante. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins in this
case and in No. 70-18, ante. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
No. 71-666. United States, appellant, v. Glaxo Group Limited
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Columbia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Columbia for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun concur.
No. 71-909. Environmental Protection Agency et al., petitioners,
2. Patsy T. Mink et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment

MONDAY, JANUARY 22, 1973
379
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall
joins concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 71–229. United States, petitioner, v. Antonio Dionisio. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan con-
curring in part and dissenting in part in this case and in No. 71-850,
post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas in this case and in
No. 71-850, post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall in this
case and in No. 71–850, post.
No. 71–850. United States, petitioner, v. Richard J. Mara, aka
Richard J. Marasovich. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in part and dis-
senting in part in this case and in No. 71–229, ante. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas in this case and in No. 71–229, ante. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall in this case and in No. 71–229,
ante.
Adjourned until Tuesday, February 20, 1973, at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

No. A-789. Sylvester J. Vaughns, Jr., et al., applicants, v. Board
of Education of Prince Georges County, Maryland, et al.; and
No. A-790. Sylvester J. Vaughns, Jr., et al., applicants, v. Board

ferred to the Court, are denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice

or decision of these applications.

510-278-73-76

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1973
381
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71–6886. Paul B. Gladden, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-5642. Homer A. Tillman, appellant, v. Maryland. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of Maryland.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 72-719. Non-Resident Taxpayers Association of Pennsylvania
and New Jersey et al., appellants, v. Charles Murray, Sheriff of Phila-
delphia County, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72–886. Charles Prigmore et al., appellants, v. Hugh Renfro
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Alabama. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72–889. Norman Tolpo et al., appellants, v. Bob Bullock, Sec-
retary of State of Texas. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Texas. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-808. Roscoe L. Anderson, appellant, v. Oregon. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. Motion to dispense with
printing jurisdictional statement granted. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-811. North Carolina Utilities Commission et al., appellants,
2. Interstate Commerce Commission et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
510-278-73-77

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1973
382
No. 72-823. Ralph Nader et al., appellants, v. United States et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Connecticut. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument on the issue of
right of intervention.
No. 72-829. Robert D. Leggett dba Investigations, Ltd., appellant,
2. State of Ohio Department of Commerce, Division of Licensing.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Hamilton County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-902. Chester Wojtycha, appellant, v. New Jersey. Appeal
from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-931. Paul R. Handlery et al., appellants, v. State of Cali-
fornia Franchise Tax Board. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-897. David Hoffman et al., appellants, v. City of Cincin-
nati. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set
case for oral argument on the issue of systematic exclusion of voters
between the ages of 18 and 21 from the jury.
No. 72-5789. Larry Warner and Ray Slaseman, etc., appellants, v.
J. A. Trombetta, Director, Pennsylvania Bureau of Traffic Safety, et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle Dis-
trict of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-811. Lydia Aguayo et al., applicants, v. Caspar W. Wein-
berger, Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare, et al. The appli-
cation for a stay or writ of injunction presented to Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. D-9. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Seymour R. Thaler.
It is ordered that Seymour R. Thaler of New York, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue
returnable within forty days requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 59, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. States of
Nevada and California. The motion of Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe
of Indians for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae,
is denied.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1973
383
No. 71-1442. Roland V. Colgrove, petitioner, v. James F. Battin,
United States District Judge for the District of Montana. The motion
of California Trial Lawyers Association for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, in support of petitioner, is granted.
No. 71-1553. John J. Gilligan, Governor of Ohio, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Craig Morgan et al. The motion of the petitioners to re-
strict the issues is denied inasmuch as the issues upon which cer-
tiorari is granted cannot be expanded by an amicus curiae. See Rule
23(1)(c).
No. 71-1623. Bob Bullock, etc., appellant, v. Dan Weiser et al.
The motion of the appellees to divide oral argument is denied.
No. 72–178. Susan R. Struck, petitioner, v. Secretary of Defense
et al. The motion for double costs is denied.
No. 72–212. Hoyt C. Cupp, Superintendent, Oregon State Peni-
tentiary, petitioner, v. Daniel P. Murphy. The motion of Americans
for Effective Law Enforcement, Inc., et al., for leave to file a brief,
as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 72-535. United States and Interstate Commerce Commission,
appellants, v. Students Challenging Regulatory Agency Procedures
(S.C.R.A.P.), et al.; and
No. 72-562. Aberdeen and Rockfish Railroad Company et al., ap-
pellants, v. Students Challenging Regulatory Agency Procedures
(S.C.R.A.P.), et al. The motion of appellee Students Challenging
Regulatory Agency Procedures (S.C.R.A.P.) for leave to dispense
with printing brief is granted. The motion of appellants for additional
time for oral argument is granted and fifteen additional minutes are
allotted for that purpose. The appellees are likewise granted fifteen
additional minutes for oral argument. The motion of John F. Banzhaf,
III, Esquire, to permit Peter H. Meyers, Esquire, to argue pro hac vice
on behalf of appellee S.C.R.A.P. is granted. The motion of Philip
Elman, Esquire, to permit John F. Dienelt, Esquire, to argue pro hac
vice on behalf of appellees Environmental Defense Fund et al. is
granted.
No. 72-846. B. Dale Ball, Director of the Department of Agricul-
ture of Michigan, et al., petitioners, v. Armour and Company et al.;
No. 72-851. The Oneida Indian Nation of New York State et al.,
petitioners, v. The County of Oneida, New York, et al.; and
No. 72-943. Dean Fisher et al., appellants, v. Martin Graves et al.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in each of these cases.
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 72-770. Commissioner of Social Services of the State of New
York et al. appellants, v. Elizabeth Linda Klein et al.; and

384
No. 72–803. Nassau County Medical Center et al., appellants, v.

within thirty days.

No. 72-5794. Joshaway Davis, petitioner, v. Alaska. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Alaska granted limited to Question 1
presented by the petition which reads as follows:

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1973
385
"1. Did the trial court err in not permitting cross examination of
chief identification witness Green concerning the nature of his juve-
nile record to bring before the jury the fact that Green was himself
on probation for burglary at the time of the identification, thereby
denying petitioner his Sixth Amendment right to confrontation?"
No. 72-5847. Harrell Alexander, Sr., petitioner, v. Gardner-Den-

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit granted.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 71-1637. City of Burbank et al., appellants, v. Lockheed Air
Terminal Inc., et al. Two hours allowed for oral argument. Argued
by Mr. Richard L. Sieg, Jr., for the appellants, by Mr. Nicholas C.
Yost for the State of California, as amicus curiae, by special leave of
Court, by Mr. Daniel M. Friedman for the United States, as amicus
curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Warren M. Christopher
for the appellees.
No. 71-6481. Clifford H. Davis, petitioner, v. United States.
Argued by Mr. Melvin L. Wulf for the petitioner and by Mr. Edward
R. Korman for the respondent.
No. 72-95. Lewis S. Tollett, Warden, petitioner, v. Willie Lee
Henderson. Argued by Mr. R. Jackson Rose for the petitioner and
by Mr. H. Fred Hoefle for the respondent.
No. 72-77. Delores Norwood et al., appellants, v. D. L. Harrison,
Sr., et al. Argument commenced by Mr. Melvyn R. Leventhal for the
appellants.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1973
418
OPINIONS
No. 71-364. Joan S. Mahan, Secretary, State Board of Elections,
et al., appellants, v. Henry E. Howell, Jr., et al.; and
No. 71–373. City of Virginia Beach, appellant, v. Henry E. How-
ell, Jr., et al.; and
No. 71-444. Robert L. Weinberg, appellant, v. Edgar A. Prichard
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Virginia. Judgment in Nos. 71-364 and 71-373 affirmed
in part and reversed in part and cases remanded to the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Judgment in
No. 71-444 affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in part with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 71-718. Paul D. McGinnis, Commissioner of Correction, State
of New York, et al., appellants, v. James Royster et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Southern District of New
York. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States.
District Court for the Southern District of New York for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with
whom Mr. Justice Marshall concurs.
No. 71-5908. Leon Chambers, petitioner, v. Mississippi. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Mississippi for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 71-6060. Anthony Louis Tacon, petitioner, v. Arizona. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Writ of certiorari
dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall concur.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 72-77. Delores Norwood et al., appellants, v. D. L. Harrison,
Sr., et al. Argument continued by Mr. William A. Allain for the appel-
lees and concluded by Mr. Melvyn R. Leventhal for the appellants.
No. 72-11. Roosevelt F. Palmore, appellant, v. United States.
One and half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Frank
F. Flegal for the appellant and by Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N.
Griswold for the appellee.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1973
419
No. 71-1523. Richard W. Hunt, appellant, v. Robert E. McNair,
Governor of South Carolina, et al. Argued by Mr. Robert McCormick
Figg, Jr., for the appellant and by Mr. Huger Sinkler for the ap-
pellees.
No. 72-75. Georgia et al., appellants, v. United States. Argument
commenced by Mr. Harold N. Hill, Jr., for the appellants and con-
tinued by Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the appellee.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 71-1193. United States, appellant, v. Travis Paul Enmons
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist concur.
No. 71-685. Robert J. Lehnhausen, petitioner, v. Lake Shore Auto
Parts Co., et al.; and
No. 71-691. Edward J. Barrett, County Clerk of Cook County,
Illinois, et al., petitions, v. Clemens K. Shapiro et al. On writs of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment reversed and cases
remanded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. 71-991. Otter Tail Power Company, appellant, v. United
States. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Minnesota. Judgment affirmed in part and vacated in part and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the District of Min-
nesota for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stew-
art concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Mr. Justice Black-

421
mun and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this case.
No. 30, Original. State of Michigan, plaintiff, v. State of Ohio.
On Bill of Complaint. Decree entered. Opinion per curiam announced
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
No. 71-6698. Marion P. Morris, on behalf of Linda Morris, peti-
tioner, v. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and
Welfare. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently
granted. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 72–686. Department of Motor Vehicles of the State of Cali-
fornia, petitioner, v. Federico Rios, a minor, etc. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Su-
preme Court of California for further proceedings as may be appro-
priate. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-89. Samuel U. Rodgers, M.D., et al., appellants, v. John C.
Danforth, Attorney General of the State of Missouri, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Western District of
Missouri. Motion of appellees to dismiss for failure to timely docket
appeal denied. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Western District of Missouri for further
consideration in light of Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. — (1973), and Doe v.
Bolton, 410 U.S. — (1973).
No. 70-105. Edward V. Hanrahan, State's Attorney of Cook
County, Illinois, appellant, v. Jane Doe and Sally Roe, etc., et al.; and
No. 70-106. Bart Heffernan, guardian ad litem, appellant, v. Jane
Doe and Sally Roe, etc., et al. Appeals from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Motion to vacate stay here-
tofore granted by Mr. Justice Marshall is granted. Judgment vacated
and cases remanded to the United States District Court for the North-
ern District of Illinois for further consideration in light of Roe v.
Wade, 410 U.S. — (1973).
-
No. 71-92. Elizabeth Corkey et al., appellants, v. Dan K. Edwards
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western

District of North Carolina. Judgment vacated and case remanded to

et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western

No. 72-56. Arnold Markle et al., appellants, v. Janice Abele et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Con-
necticut. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the District of Connecticut for consideration of the
question of mootness of this appeal.
No. 72–256. Phillip Crossen, Pat Craddock, and Peter Scott, ap-
pellants, v. Attorney General of the Commonwealth of Kentucky et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Kentucky. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky
for further consideration in light of Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. — (1973).
No. 72-434. Robert M. Byrn, guardian ad litem for infant Roe,
etc., appellant, v. New York City Health & Hospitals Corporation et
al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. Motion to post-
pone jurisdiction until a hearing of the appeal on the merits denied.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Roe
v. Wade, 410 U.S. — (1973).
No. 72–631. H. Benjamin Munson, appellant, v. South Dakota.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Dakota. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of South Dakota for fur-
ther consideration in light of Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. — (1973).
-

States District Court for the District of Connecticut for further
consideration in light of Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. — (1973), and Doe v.
Bolton, 410 U.S. — (1973).

No. 72-806. Ramsay Travel, Incorporated, et al., appellants, v.

want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.

Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of
this appeal.
No. 72–5935. L. G. Ruderer, appellant, v. Richard Kleindienst,
Attorney General. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or
decision of this appeal.

of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. Petition for writ of cer-

Court of Ohio for further consideration in light of Roe v. Wade, 410
U.S. — (1973).

for stay and/or bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.

Governor of South Carolina, et al. The motion of the Attorney Gen-
eral of New Jersey for leave to file an untimely brief, as amicus curiae,
is granted.

No. 72-271. Cathedral Academy et al., appellants, v. Committee

No. 72-488. Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, petitioner, v.

IS GRANTED.

Green. The motion of The Chamber of Commerce of the United States
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.

Dombrowski. The motion of respondent for the appointment of coun-
sel is granted, and it is ordered that William J. Mulligan, Esquire, of
Milwaukee, Wisconsin, a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he
is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 72–1139. James Grit et al., appellants, v. Benson A. Wolman
et al. The motion to expedite and to advance oral argument is denied.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1973
426
No. 72–844. E. E. Falk, Individually and as Partner in Drucker &
Falk, et al., petitioners, v. Peter J. Brennan, Secretary of Labor,
United States Department of Labor. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted
limited to Quesions 2 and 3 presented by the petition which read as
follows:
"2. Under the Fair Labor Standards Act to be covered an enter-
prise must have an 'annual gross volume of sales made or business
done' of $500,000. Is this figure to be measured by the gross rentals
collected by the agent or by that agent's gross commissions?
"3. Are maintenance workers employed at the buildings managed
by petitioners employees of the apartment owner or of the peti-
tioners?"
No. 72-5581. Richard Guy Steffel, petitioner, v. John R. Thomp-
son et al. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit granted.

States. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit granted.

Patent Office et al.;

No. 72-5608. Carol Jean Heindl, petitioner, v. Washington Termi-
nal Company;

Warden;

bia;
No. 72-5649. James C. Milstead and Rose Marie Milstead, peti-
tioners, v. California et al.;
No. 72-5682. Marlyn Lee Jones, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 72–5716. John C. Bennett, petitioner, v. United States Di-
rector of Internal Revenue; and
No. 72–5735. Juergen Stengel, petitioner, v. City of Anaheim,
County of Orange, et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 71-858. Thomas Ricci, petitioner, v. Chicago Merchantile Ex-
change et al. Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Peti-
tion for rehearing denied.
No. 72–277. Henry C. Fortenberry, etc., petitioner, v. New York
Life Insurance Company. Motion for leave to file petition for rehear-
ing denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for the week of April 2, 1973, and
for such further time as may be required to complete unfinished busi-
ness, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes
of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for the week of May 21,
1973, and for such further time as may be required to complete un-
finished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered
on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1973

433
The Court will take a recess from Monday, March 5, 1973, until
Monday, March 19, 1973.

OPINIONS
No. 71–692. Illinois, petitioner, v. Donald Somerville. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
White with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan join.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 71-1022. United States, petitioner, v. James A. Basye et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgments reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals with directions that judgments be entered for the United
States. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
No. 71-1136. Murray Tillman et al., petitioners, v. Wheaton-
Haven Recreation Association, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun.

No. 71–873. United States, appellant, v. Falstaff Brewing Corpo-
ration et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Rhode Island. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas con-
curring in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in the
result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr.
Justice Stewart concurs. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the deci-
sion of this case. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.

conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 5, 1973
443
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 72-5431. Raymond N. Ortwein and Gwendolyn Faubion, ap-
pellants, v. Herbert M. Schwab et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Oregon. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Judgment affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Stewart dis-
sents, believing that the doctrine of Boddie v. Connecticut, 401 U.S. 371
(1971), requires reversal of this judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-759. California-Pacific Utilities Company et al., appel-
lants, v. United tSates et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Colorado. Appeal as to California-Pacific
Utilities Company dismissed for want of jurisdiction for failure to
file a timely notice of appeal. 28 U.S.C. 2101 (b). Judgment as to the
six other appellants affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White
and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 72-768. Arizona ex rel. the State Corporation Commission
et al., appellants, v. United States et al.;
No. 72-779. Southwest Gas Corporation, appellant, v. United
States et al.;
No. 72-781. Pacific Gas and Electric Company, appellant, v. El
Paso Natural Gas Company et al.; and
No. 72-785. El Paso Natural Gas Company et al., appellants, v.
United States et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for
the District of Colorado. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice White, and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of these cases.
No. 72-865. City of Petersburg, Virginia, appellant, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
510-278-73-89

MONDAY, MARCH 5, 1973
444
District of Columbia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 72-876. Curtis, Inc., appellant, v. United States and Inter-
state Commerce Commission. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Colorado. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-998. John Lehane et al., appellants, v. City and County of
San Francisco et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-839. Eugene L. Smaldone, appellant, v. United States.
The application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 71-1553. John J. Gilligan, Governor of Ohio, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Craig Morgan et al. The motion of the Solicitor General
for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, on behalf
of the petitioners is granted and fifteen minutes are allotted for that
purpose. The respondents are allotted fifteen additional minutes for
oral argument.
No. 71-1647. Federal Maritime Commission, petitioner, v. Sea-
train Lines, Inc., et al. The motion of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 72-11. Roosevelt F. Palmore, appellant, v. United States.
The motion of the appellant for leave to file a supplemental brief, after
argument, is granted.
No. 72-269. Arthur Levitt, as Comptroller of the State of New
York and Ewald B. Nyquist, as Commissioner of Education of the
State of New York, appellants, v. Committee for Public Education
and Religious Liberty et al.;
No. 72-270. Warren M. Anderson, as Majority Leader and Presi-
dent pro tem of New York State Senate, appellant, v. Committee for
Public Education and Religious Liberty et al.; and
No. 72-271. Cathedral Academy et al., appellants, v. Committee
for Public Education and Religious Liberty et al. The motion of the
appellants to permit two counsel to argue orally is granted.
No. 72-419. Pittsburgh Press Company, petitioner, v. The Pitts-
burgh Commission on Human Relations et al. The motion of The In-
ternational Association of Official Human Rights Agencies for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of The Amer-
ican Civil Liberties Union, etc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted.

MONDAY, MARCH 5, 1973
445
No. 72-493. John W. Vlandis, Director of Admissions, the Uni-
versity of Connecticut, appellant, v. Margaret Marsh Kline and Pat-
ricia Catapano. The motion of the American Civil Liberties Union
of Ohio, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 72-634. United States Civil Service Commission et al., ap-
pellants, v. National Association of Letter Carriers, AFL-CIO, et al.
The motion of the appellees for additional time for oral argument
is granted and ten additional minutes are allotted for that purpose.
The appellants are granted ten additional minutes for oral argument.

State of New York, et al., appellants, v. Committee for Public Educa-
tion and Religious Liberty et al.; and
No. 72–929. Priscilla L. Cherry et al., appellants, v. Committee for
Public Education and Religious Liberty et al. The motion of Sidney A.
Seegers et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 72-730. Arnold Markle et al., appellants, v. Janice Abele et al.
The stay heretofore granted by this Court on October 16, 1972, is
hereby vacated.
No. 72-1138. Harold W. Harrison, petitioner, v. United States.
The application for a stay or recall of the mandate of the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit presented to Mr. Justice
Powell, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.

OPINIONS
No. 27, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Commonwealth of
Kentucky. On motion for leave to file amended bill of complaint. Mo-
tion for leave to file amended bill of complaint denied. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 71–862. United Air Lines, Inc., appellant, v. George E. Mahin
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice White concur. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 71-1304. Charles B. Bradley, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall. Statement by Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White
joining Part I of the Court's opinion and would affirm for reasons there
expressed. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 71-6078. Linda R. S. et al., appellants, v. Richard D. and
Texas et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Texas. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom
Mr. Justice Douglas joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 71-6742. Felipe Juarez Hurtado et al., petitioners, v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Western District of Texas for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring
in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
Adjourned until Monday, March 19, 1973, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1973
456
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 72-794. Barbara Susan Papish, petitioner, v. The Board of
Curators of the University of Missouri et al. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Western
District of Missouri for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist with whom the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
No. 72–899. Paul N. Marston et al., appellants, v. Anita X. Lewis
and Catherine Mandt. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Arizona. Judgment, insofar as it has been appealed
from, reversed and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the Disirict of Arizona for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Brennan concur.
No. 72-901. Kathryn Burns et al., appellants, v. Ben Fortson, etc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam. State-
ment by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan
concur.
No. 72–905. J. Edwin La Vallee, Superintendent of Clinton Cor-
rectional Facility, petitioner, v. Pasquale Delle Rose. On Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
510-278-73-91

MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1973
457
curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart
concur.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-608. Colorado in the Interest of L. B., et al., appellants, v.
L. V. B. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72–1008. The City of Piney Point Village, Texas, et al., ap-
pellants, v. Harris County, Texas, et al. Appeal from the Court of
Civil Appeals of the State of Texas, First Supreme Judicial District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-1021. Barry and Barry, Inc., et al., appellants, v. State of
Washington, Department of Motor Vehicles, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 72-849. John Lawrence Avery, appellant, v. Maryland. Ap-
peal from the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-990. Edgar D. Whitcomb, etc., et al., appellants, v. Com-
munist Party of Indiana et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Indiana. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-996. Joseph M. Koelfgen et al., appellants, v. John Jackson
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Minnesota. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-5960. Jim Fair et al., appellants, v. Richard Nixon et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 72-6082. Jerry Shaffer, etc., appellant, v. John O. Graham,
Commissioner, State Department of Public Welfare, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division Two. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is de-
nied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-5. In matter of Disbarment of Burton R. Signer. It
having been reported to the Court that Burton R. Signer, of
Cincinnati, Ohio, has been disbarred from the practice of law by the

MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1973
458
Supreme Court of Ohio, duly entered June 28, 1972, and this Court by
order of November 6, 1972, having suspended the said Burton R.
Signer from the practice of law in this Court and directing that a rule
issue requiring him to show cause why he should not disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon
the respondent, and that a response thereto has been filed;
It is ordered that the said Burton R. Signer be, and he is hereby,
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
bar of this Court.
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New York et al. The supplemental report of the Special
Master is hereby adopted by the Court.
No. 60, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New York et al. The motion for leave to file bill of com-
plaint is denied. Mr. Justice Stewart would set the motion for leave
to file bill of complaint for oral argument.
No. 71-1182. Raymond Mattz, petitioner, v. G. Raymond Arnett,
etc. The motion of petitioner to divide oral argument is granted.
No. 72-402. United States, appellant, v. General Dynamics Cor-
poration et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for additional time
for oral argument is granted and fifteen additional minutes are al-
lotted for that purpose. The appellees are allotted fifteen additional
minutes for oral argument.
No. 72-419. Pittsburgh Press Company, petitioner, v. The Pitts-
burgh Commission on Human Relations et al. The motion to permit
two counsel to argue orally on behalf of the respondents is granted.
No. 72-459. Grace Sloan, as State Treasurer of the Commonwealth
of Pennsylvania, et al., appellants, v. Alton J. Lemon et al.; and
No. 72-620. Henry E. Crouter, appellant, v. Alton J. Lemon et al.
The motion of the Attorney General of Pennsylvania for additional
time for oral argument is granted and fifteen additional minutes are
allotted for that purpose. The appellees are allotted fifteen additional
minutes for oral argument.

Light, Gas and Water Division et al.; and
No. 72-488. Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, petitioner, v.
Memphis Light, Gas and Water Division et al. The motion to permit
two counsel to argue orally on behalf the respondents is granted.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Indiana
denied for want of standing of the petitioner. Doremus et al. v. Board
of Education of the Borough of Hawthorne et al., 342 U.S. 429. Mr.
Justice Douglas would deny certiorari on the grounds that petitioner,
who was convicted of performing an abortion, is not a doctor and
that the decisions of this Court in Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. and Doe
v. Bolton, 410 U.S. were confined to the condition: inter alia,
that the abortion, if performed, be based on an appropriately safe-
guarded medical judgment.
-
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 72-5592. David Goldsmith, petitioner, v. Wyoming et al.;
and
No. 72-5849. John J. Reardon, petitioner, v. Lenard F. Meacham
et al. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of habeas corpus
denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 72-6100. Joseph P. Gerardi, petitioner, v. Dudley E. Faver,
Director, Discharge Review Board; and
No. 72-6129. Joseph P. Gerardi, petitioner, v. William A. Mac-
Laughlin et al. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of man-
damus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 72-6035. L. G. Ruderer, petitioner, v. John J. Sirica, Judge.
Motion for leave to file petition for writ of prohibition denied. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
REHEARING DENIED
No. 72-5133. Robert Buchanan III, appellant, v. Texas. Motion
for leave to file second petition for rehearing denied.

No. 71-1553. John J. Gilligan, Governor of Ohio, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Craig Morgan et al. One and one half hours allowed for
oral argument. Argued by Mr. Thomas V. Martin for the petitioners,
by Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold, as amicus curiae, by
special leave of Court, and by Mr. Michael E. Geltner for the
respondents.
No. 72–269. Arthur Levitt, as Comptroller of the State of New
York and Ewald B. Nyquist, as Commissioner of Education of the
State of New York, appellants, v. Committee for Public Education
and Religious Liberty et al.;
No. 72–270. Warren M. Anderson, as Majority Leader and Presi-
dent pro tem of New York State Senate, appellant, v. Committee for
Public Education and Religious Liberty et al.; and
No. 72–271. Cathedral Academy et al., appellants, v. Committee
for Public Education and Religious Liberty et al. Argued by Mrs.
Jean M. Coon for the appellants Levitt et al., by Mr. Leo Pfeffer for
the appellees and by Mr. Porter R. Chandler for the appellants non-
public-schools.
No. 71-6278. Condrado Almeida-Sanchez, petitioner, v. United
States. Argument commenced by Mr. James A. Chanoux for the
petitioner. After a brief argument, the Court adjourned at 1:28 due
to the illness of counsel and reconvened at 1:44 for the next case.
No. 72–350. United States, appellant, v. State Tax Commission
of Mississippi et al. Argued by Mrs. Jewell S. Lafontant for the ap-
pellant and by Mr. Robert L. Wright for the appellees.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

No. 71–1456. Salyer Land Company et al., appellants, v. Tulare
Lake Basin Water Storage District. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of California. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.
Court will await the result of further proceedings before the Special
Master with respect to the ownership of islands in the western portion
of the Sabine. In all other respects the exceptions of the parties are
overruled and the report of the Special Master is confirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

Liners, appellants, v. Toltec Watershed Improvement District. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Wyoming. Judgment affirmed. Opin-

opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall concur.

OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 72–864. William B. Camp, Comptroller of the Currency of
the United States, petitioner, v. F. W. Pitts et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam.
No. 72-1010. Ohio Municipal Judges Association et al., appel-
lants, v. Arthur Davis et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Ohio. Motion of American Civil
Liberties Union of Ohio, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curae
is granted. Judgment affirmed, but on the ground that appellants'
constitutional challenge to Art. IV, § 6(B), was without merit. Opin-
ion per curiam.
"OF THE OHIO CONSTITUTION!

No. 72-1070. Don Binkowski, appellant, v. Edna Miller et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for Eastern District of
Michigan. Judgment affirmed.

the Estate of Daisy Purnell Simpson, appellant, v. The City of Uni-

No. 71-6693. Melvin Reed and William Harris, petitioners, v. City
of New Orleans. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Louisiana. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
510-278-73-
-96

MONDAY, MARCH 26, 1973
481
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for reconsideration in
light of Argersinger v. Hamlin, Sheriff, 407 U.S. 25 (1972).
No. 72-5484. Ivory George, petitioner, v. Louisiana. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed
the death penalty imposed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Louisiana for further proceedings. See Stewart v. Massachusetts,
408 U.S. 845 (1972).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 40 Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v. State
of New York et al. It is hereby ordered that John F. Davis, the Special
Master appointed in this cause, having completed his duties, is hereby
discharged.
It is further ordered that his expenditures in preparing the supple-
mental report in the amount of One Hundred and Four Dollars
($104) are approved.
It is further ordered that the compensation for the services of the
Special Master in the supplementary proceedings be fixed at One
Thousand Dollars ($1,000) and that that amount plus the approved
expenditures shall be paid to him by Western Union out of the funds
in its possession which are the subject of this suit and that Western
Union be given credit for that amount divided pro rata among the
parties who would otherwise be entitled to the money under the opinion
and decree of this Court.
No. 71-6278. Condrado Almeida-Sanchez, petitioner, v. United
States.
The motion of the Prison Research Council for the University of
Pennsylvania for leave to file an untimely brief, as amicus curiae,
is denied.
The motion for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is
ordered that John J. Cleary, Esquire, of San Diego, California, a
member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed to
serve as co-counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 71-6732. James Chaffin, petitioner, v. LeRoy Stynchcombe,
Sheriff of Fulton County. The motion of the Attorney General of
Tennessee for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, after argument, is
granted.

tion and Welfare, et al., petitioners, v. Hynson, Westcott and Dunning,

APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 72-5830. Clover Patterson, appellant, v. George Warner, etc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of West Virginia. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

dano et al. Motion of respondent Giordano for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED

petition.

ORAL ARGUMENT
492
No. 71-1417. Booster Lodge No. 405, International Association of
Machinists and Aerospace Workers, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Na-
tional Labor Relations Board et al.; and
No. 71-1607. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. The
Boeing Company et al. One and one-half hours allowed for oral argu-
ment. Argued by Mr. Bernard Dunau for Booster Lodge No. 405, etc.,
by Mr. Norton J. Come for the National Labor Relations Board, and
by Mr. Samuel Lang for the Boeing Company.
No. 72-634. United States Civil Service Commission et al, appel-
lants, v. National Association of Letter Carriers, AFL-CIO, et al.
One hour and twenty minutes allowed for oral argument. Argued by
Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold for the appellants and by
Mr. Thomas C. Matthews, Jr., for the appellees.
No. 71–1639. William M. Broadrick et al., appellants, v. Oklahoma
et al. Argued by Mr. John C. Buckingham for the appellants and by
Mr. Michael Dennis Martin for the appellees.
Adjournment until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 71-834. Rosalind McClanahan, etc., appellant, v. State Tax
Commission of Arizona. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Arizona,
Division One. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals of Arizona, Division One, for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 71-738. The Mescalero Apache Tribe, petitioner, v. Franklin
Jones, Commissioner of the Bureau of Revenue of the State of New
Mexico, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New
Mexico. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals of New Mexico for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas dissenting in
part with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart concur.
ORAL ARGUMENT

Light, Gas and Water Division, et al.; and
No. 72–488. Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, petitioner, v
Memphis Light, Gas and Water Division, et al. Argued by Mr. Samuel

New York.

OPINION
No. 71-1545. Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Glover Livestock Commission Company, Inc. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
ORAL ARGUMENT
