(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1973
496
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–795. J. D. Leathers, appellant, v. Sam Massell et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72–893. Francis D. Fox et ux., appellants, v. John H. Norberg,
Tax Administrator. Appeal from the Superior Court of Rhode Island,
Providence and Bristol Counties. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 72–1093. Variety Theaters, Inc., appellant, v. Cleveland
County, North Carolina, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
North Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 72-1106. Earl H. Hammond, appellant, v. Ramaldus G.
Hager et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Montana. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72–1114. John A. Hutter et ux., appellants, v. Bernard J.
Korzen, County Treasurer, etc. Appeal from the Appellate Court of
Illinois, First District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
No. 72-5943. Edward J. Boykin et al., appellants, v. Chester W.
Ott, Administrator, Oregon Motor Vehicles Division. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 72-997. John S. Atlee et al., appellants, v. Elliot L. Richard-
son, Individually and as Secretary of Defense, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.
Judgments affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Stewart would note probable jurisdiction and set case for
oral argument.
510-278-73-100

MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1973
497
No. 72-5919. Gwendolyn Faubion, appellant, v. Andrew Juras,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Doug-
las dissents for the reasons stated in his dissenting opinion in Ort-
wein v. Schwab 410 U.S.
(1973).
-
No. 72–6025. James Briggs and Anthony Datzuk, appellants, v.
Mehadin K. Arafeh et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Connecticut. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Powell dissent from the affirmance.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-1075. Bachrodt Chevrolet Co., petitioner, v. National Labor
Relations Board. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for cer-
tiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals with instructions to remand case to the National Labor
Relations Board for such further proceedings as may be appropriate
in light of NLRB v. Burns International Security Services, Inc., 406
U.S. 272 (1972); FTC v. Sperry & Hutchinson Co., 405 U.S. 233, 245–
250 (1972); SEC v. Chenery Corp., 318 U.S. 80, 87-88 (1943).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-987. L. G. Ruderer, petitioner, v. Daniel Bartlett, Jr. The
motion for leave to file petition for injuctive order presented to Mr.
Justice Blackmun, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
notion.
No. 48, Original. State of Mississippi, plaintiff, v. State of Arkan-
sas. The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed.
Exceptions, if any, with supporting briefs to the Report may be filed
by the parties on or before May 17, 1973. Reply briefs, if any, to
such exceptions may be filed on or before June 18, 1973.
No. 72-459. Grace Sloan, as State Treasurer of the Commonwealth
of Pennsylvania, et al., appellants, v. Alton J. Lemon et al.; and
No. 72–620. Henry E. Crouter, appellant, v. Alton J. Lemon et al.
The motion of the National Association of Independent Schools, Inc.,
for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae. is denied.

petitioners, v. State Board of Education of the Commonwealth of Vir-
ținia et al.; and
No. 72–550. Carolyn Bradley et al., petitioners, v. State Board of
Education of the Commonwealth of Virginia et al. The motion of
he Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument, as

amicus curiae, in support of respondents is granted and fifteen min-

ronmental Protection Agency, petitioner, v. Sierra Club et al. The mo-

as amici curiae, is denied.
No. 72–1187. M. Browning Combs et al., petitioners, v. Princess
Ranola Johnson et al. The motion to advance and for pendente lite
relief is denied.
No. 72-5881. Robert Edward Marshall, petitioner, v. United States.
The motion for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered
that James F. Hewitt, Esquire, of San Francisco, California, a mem-
ber of the Bar of this Court be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as
counsel for the petitioner in this case.

REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 72-5431. Raymond N. Ortwein and Gwendolyn Faubion, ap-
pellants, v. Herbert M. Schwab et al;
No. 72-5712. Donald W. Higginbotham, petitioner, v. United
States;
No. 72-5779. David Jackson, Jr., petitioner, v. United States;
No. 72-5803. Edward McCray, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 72-5872. Homer L. Thomas and Willie Watson, petitioners, v.
Mississippi; and
No. 72-5885. Calvin Sellars, petitioner, v. W. J. Estelle, Director,
Texas Department of Corrections. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 71–364. Joan S. Mahan, Secretary, State Board of Elections,
et al., appellants, v. Henry E. Howell, Jr.,
et al.; and
No. 71–373. City of Virginia Beach, appellant, v. Henry E. Howell,
Jr., et al. Treating the petition for rehearing in No. 71-373 as a motion
to modify the Court's opinion, the following order is hereby entered:
"The motion of the appellant, City of Virginia Beach, to modify this
Court's opinion is hereby granted. The first paragraph in Part II of
the opinion is amended by adding a portion of after the phrase
'Under the plan,' in the second sentence thereof, and by striking the
phrase 'encompassing the cities of Norfolk and Virginia Beach' in
the last sentence of the paragraph, substituting therefor the following
phrase: 'encompassing the City of Norfolk and a portion of Virginia
Beach.'".
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision
of this order.
No. 72–826. Ignatius J. Broussard, Jr., petitioner, v. Roderick R.
Patton, etc., et al. Motion of James Abourezk et al., for leave to file.
a brief, as amici curiae, in support of petition for rehearing granted.
Petition for rehearing denied.

MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1973
OPINIONS
512
No. 71-1470. Alton J. Lemon et al., appellants, v. David H. Kurtz-
man, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Chief
Justice Burger announced the judgment of this Court and delivered
an opinion in which Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and
Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Mr. Justice White concurs in the judg-
inent. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart concur. Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 71-6757. David X. Fontaine, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals to the end that the petitioner be afforded a hearing on his
petition in the District Court. Opinion per curiam announced by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice White dissents.
Adjourned until Monday, April 16, 1973, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1973
513
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 72-805. United States, petitioner, v. Alphonse T. Indrelunas.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment reversed, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-925. Melvin B. Palkes, dba Madison Iron & Metal Com-
pany, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illi-
nois. The appeal is dismissed for want of a final judgment.
No. 72–1025. B.P.O.E. Lodge No. 2043 of Brunswick et al., appel-
lants, v. Keith H. Ingraham et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial
Court of Maine. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun concur.
No. 72-1128. Allan Roy Kingston et al., appellants, v. Walter H.
McLaughlin et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Massachusetts. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-6153. L. G. Ruderer, appellant, v. United States Army
Aviation Materiel Command et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Illinois. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this appeal.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1028. Worcester City Hospital et al., applicants, v. Robbie
Mae Hathaway. The application for a stay of the mandate of the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit presented to Mr.
Justice Brennan, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
510-278-73- -103

MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1973
514
No. 72-394. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion, and Welfare, et al., petitioners, v. Hynson, Westcott and Dunning,
Incorporated;
No. 72-414. Hynson, Westcott and Dunning, Incorporated, peti-
tioner, v. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education, and
Welfare, et al.;
No. 72–528. CIBA Corporation, petitioner, v. Caspar W. Wein-
berger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, et al.;
No. 72-555. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion, and Welfare, et al., petitioners, v. Bentex Pharmaceuticals, Inc.,
et al.; and
No. 72-666. USV Pharmaceutical Corporation, petitioner, v.
Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare,
et al. The motion of The American Public Health Association et al.,
for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. The motion of The
Pharmaceuticas Manufacturers Association for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of The Proprietary Association
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 72-459. Grace Sloan, as State Treasurer of the Commonwealth
of Pennsylvania, et al., appellants, v. Alton J. Lemon et al.; and
No. 72-620. Henry E. Crouter, appellant, v. Alton J. Lemon et al.
The motion of The National Education Association et al., for leave to
file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 72-804. William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the En-
vironmental Protection Agency, petitioner, v. Sierra Club et al. The
motion of the State of Michigan for additional time and for leave to
present oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas,
Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice White would grant the motion.
No. 72–5794. Joshaway Davis, petitioner, v. Alaska. The motion
of Arthur Bembury for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is
granted.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 72-5704. Jean Christian and Victor L. Green, appellants, v.
New York State Department of Labor, Division of Employment, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of New York. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 72-1154. John P. Foley, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. Blair & Co.,
Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 59, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. States of

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, APRIL 17, 1973
534
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Before proceeding with our regular matters this morning, we will
pause for a moment to take note of an important anniversary of our
Brother, Mr. Justice William O. Douglas. Thirty-four years ago today
he took the oath of office as an Associate Justice of this Court and in
the history of this Court, only Chief Justice Marshall, our late Broth-
er Justice Black and Justice Field served longer. Very soon Justice
Douglas will surpass the record of even those three Justices. In his
long career on this Court he has been a strong, articulate individualist
willing to blaze new trails whether in the majority or in dissent but
also willing to tread ancient paths of the law.
"Several qualities distinguish Justice Douglas from many other
illustrious predecessors on the Court but I will mention only one. He
is possessed of a restless, questing mind and spirit not only in the law
but in relation to the world around him and in the events of his time.
On his vacations he has climbed mountains, visited strange parts of
strange lands and he has written and lectured about them. He has also
written of current developments on the social, economic and political
scene and for all of his life he has been devoted to nature and the out-
door life. He was a student of ecology before the word had currency
1. and in his concern for man's environment he was far ahead of his time.
His service on the Court spans the tenure of five Chief Justices and by
the end of this Term of Court his opinions will appear in 103 volumes
or more than one-fourth of all volumes of reported cases of the Court.
"I know I speak for all Justices and retired Justices on this anni-
versary in extending to you, Bill, our best wishes for continued good
health, long life and much happiness and many more mountains to
climb."
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTIONS

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71–1263. Edmund D. Kahn et ux., appellants, v. Arizona State
Tax Commission. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Arizona. Mo-
tion to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement granted. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Bren-
nan concurs.
No. 72-871. Michael Silvers, appellant, v. Clarence Dowling,
Judge, Civil District Court, Orleans Parish, Louisiana, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Motion to dispense with print-
ing the jurisdictional statement and motion to dispense with printing
motion to dismiss or affirm granted. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-993. Louis Sager et ux., appellants, v. Burgess and
Borough Council of Pottstown et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 72-1104. R-C Motor Lines, Inc., appellant, v. United States
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-1007. Joseph A. Mullarkey, Individually and as Adminis-
trator of the Estate of John B. Mullarkey, a minor, appellant, v.
Florida Feed Mills, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 72-1206. Reader's Digest Association, Inc., appellant, v.
Washington. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
510-278-73-108

MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1973
540
No. 72-1234. Jerome Silverman, as Administrator of the Estate
of Harold Nathan, et al., appellants, v. Louis D. Browning et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Con-
necticut. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable
jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 72–6255. L. G. Ruderer, appellant, v. United States et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
appeal.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 72-1130. Ivo H. Denham and Geraldine A. Denham, dba The
Denham Company, petitioners, v. National Labor Relations Board. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals with instructions
to remand case to the National Labor Relations Board for such further
proceedings as may be appropriate, in light of Burns International
Security Services, Inc. v. NLRB, 406 U.S. 272 (1972). FTC v. Sperry
& Hutchinson Co., 405 U.S. 233, 245-250, (1972); SEC v. Chenery
Corp., 318 U.S. 80, 87-88 (1943).
No. 72-6347. Robert Bumpus, petitioner, v. Massachusetts. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Mas-
sachusetts. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts for reconsideration
in light of Ham v. South Carolina, 409 U.S. 524 (1973).

et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of certiorari denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 72-6298. Albert H. Carter, petitioner, v. U.S. Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to file petition for
writ of mandamus denied.

ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the term upon the conclusion of the arguments
in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, April 24, 1973, until
Monday, May 7, 1973.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
OPINIONS
No. 71-1585. United States, petitioner, v. Richard Russell. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan concurs. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall join.
No. 72-11. Roosevelt F. Palmore, appellant, v. United States.
Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. Appeal
dismissed. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is granted, limited to the
question of whether Palmore was entitled to be tried by a court or-
dained and established in accordance with Art. III, § 1, of the
Constitution. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 71-1031. Leonard Tonasket, appellant, v. Washington et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Washington for recon-
sideration in light of §§ 6 and 7 of c. 157, 1972 Session Laws of the
State of Washington and this Court's decision in McClanahan v.
Arizona State Tax Comm'n, 410 U.S.
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
(1973). Opinion per curiam
No. 71–829. Leila Mourning, petitioner, v. Family Publications
Service, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Berger.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas dissenting in part with whom
Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist concur. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
510-278-73-
-110

TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1973
ORAL ARGUMENT
553
No. 72-656. Orval C. Logue et al., petitioners, v. United States.
Argued by Mr. James DeAnda for the petitioners and by Mr. Mark L.
Evans for the respondent.
No. 72-5521. Clarence Eugene Strunk, petitioner, v. United States.
Argued by Mr. John R. Wideikis for the petitioner, pro hac vice, by
special leave of Court, and by Mr. William Bradford Reynolds for the
respondent.
ORDERED:
ORDER
1. That the rules and forms as approved by the Judicial Conference
of the United States, to be known as the Bankruptcy Rules and Official
Bankruptcy Forms, be, and they hereby are, prescribed pursuant to
Section 2075, Title 28, United States Code, to govern the forms of
process, writs, pleadings, and motions, and the practice and procedure
under the Bankruptcy Act, in the proceedings and to the extent set
forth therein, in the United States district courts, the District Court
for the District of the Canal Zone, and the District Courts of Guam
and the Virgin Islands.
2. That the aforementioned Bankruptcy Rules and Official Bank-
ruptcy Forms shall take effect on October 1, 1973, and shall be appli-
cable to proceedings then pending, except to the extent that in the
opinion of the court their application in a particular proceeding then
pending would not be feasible or would work injustice, in which event
the former procedure applies.
3. That General Orders in Bankruptcy 1 to 7 inclusive, 9 to 12
inclusive, 14 to 26 inclusive, 28 to 40 inclusive, 42 to 45 inclusive,
47, 50, 51, 53, and 56 and Official Forms in Bankruptcy 1 to 13 inclu-
sive, 15 to 20 inclusive, 22 to 47 inclusive, and 70 to 72 inclusive, here-
tofore prescribed by this Court, be, and they hereby are, abrogated,
effective October 1, 1973.
4. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit the said new Bankruptcy Rules and Official Bankruptcy
Forms to the Congress at its present session on or before the first day
of May, 1973.
ORDERED:
1. That the rules and forms as approved by the Judicial Conference
of the United States, to be known as the Chapter XIII Rules and
Official Chapter XIII Forms, be, and they hereby are, prescribed pur-
suant to Section 2075, Title 28, United States Code, to govern the
forms of process, writs, pleadings, and motions and the practice and
procedure under Chapter XIII of the Bankruptcy Act, in the pro-
ceedings and to the extent set forth therein, in the United States.

TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1973
554
district courts, the District Court for the District of the Canal Zone,
and the District Courts of Guam and the Virgin Islands.
2. That the aforementioned Chapter XIII Rules and Official Chap-
ter XIII Forms shall take effect on October 1, 1973, and shall be appli-
cable to proceedings then pending, except to the extent that in the
opinion of the court their application in a particular proceeding then
pending would not be feasible or would work injustice, in which event
the former procedure applies.
3. That General Order in Bankruptcy 55 and Official Forms in
Bankruptcy 58 to 62 inclusive, heretofore prescribed by this Court, be,
and they hereby are, abrogated, effective October 1, 1973.
4. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit the said new Chapter XIII Rules and Official Chapter XIII
Forms to the Congress at its present session on or before the first day
of May, 1973.
Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
Adjourned until Monday, May 7, 1973, at 10 o'clock.

this order.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice

The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 72–6011. Frank X. Gaca, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals with instructions that the
appeal be reinstated. Opinion per curiam.
No. 72–6258. New Jersey Welfare Rights Organization et al.,
appellants, v. William T. Cahill, etc., et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of New Jersey. Motion for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted, judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the District of New
Jersey for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. The Chief Justice concurs in the result.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-9. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Seymour R. Thaler.
It having been reported that Seymour R. Thaler of New York,
New York, has been disbarred from the practice of law in all of the
courts of the State of New York, and this Court by order of February
20, 1973, having suspended the said Seymour R. Thaler from the prac-
tice of law in this Court and directed that a rule issue requiring him
to show cause why he should not be disbarred:
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served
upon the respondent and that the time within which to file a return
to the rule has expired;

MONDAY, MAY 7, 1973
558
It is ordered that the said Seymour R. Thaler be, and he is hereby,
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before
the Bar of this Court.
No. 72-812. Thomas Tone Storer et al., appellants, v. Edmund G.
Brown, Jr., et al. The motion of the Committee for Democratic Elec-
tion Laws for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in support of the
appellants, is granted.
No. 72-1428. Jesse Alexander Eller et al., petitioners, v. Sylvester
J. Vaughns, Jr., by his father and next friend, Sylvester J. Vaughns,
et al. The motion to advance and for pendente lite relief is denied.

OPINIONS
Jr.
No. 71-1665. United States, petitioner, v. Douglas B. Cartwright,
as Executor of the Estate of Ethel B. Bennett. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and
Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 71-653. Thomas S. Gibson et al., appellants, v. L. M. Berryhill
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle Dis-
trict of Alabama. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan joins.

MONDAY, MAY 7, 1973
579
No. 71-1059. Kern County Land Company, petitioner, v. Occi-
dental Petroleum Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart
concur.
No. 71-1369. Peter Preiser, Commissioner of Correctional Serv-
ices, et al., petitioners, v. Eugene Rodriguez et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 72-75. Georgia et al., appellants, v. United States. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia. Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Georgia for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring
in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom
Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 72-486. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Memphis
Light, Gas and Water Division et al.; and
No. 72–488. Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, petitioner v.
Memphis Light, Gas and Water Division, et al. On writs of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 71-1583. Edmund G. Brown, Jr., Secretary of State of Cali-
fornia, appellant, v. Raymond G. Chote. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Northern District of California. Action
taken by the District Court in granting interim relief affirmed and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of California for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, May 14, 1973, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 14, 1973
580
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-264. Mary Evelyn Parker, Treasurer of the State of
Louisiana, et al., appellants, v. Bernard B. Levy et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana.
Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-6446. Anita Winston and Gwendolyn Jackson, appellants,
v. William J. Scott, Attorney General of Illinois, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-1112. Coffee-Rich, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Jerry W.
Fielder et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Sec-
ond Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 72-1287. Charles J. Mager et ux., appellants, v. Hilltown
Township. Appeal from the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–965. United States, petitioner, v. Willie Lee Knight. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of U.S. v. Russell, 411 U.S. - (1973).
-
No. 72-1240. Spitzer Akron, Inc., petitioner, v. National Labor
Relations Board. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals with instructions to remand case to the National Labor
Relations Board for such further proceedings as may be appropriate
510-278-73-115

MONDAY, MAY 14, 1973
581
in light of Burns International Security Services, Inc. v. NLRB, 406
U.S. 272 (1972). FTC. v. Sperry & Hutchinson Co., 405 U.S. 233,
245-250 (1972); SEC v. Chenery Corp., 318 U.S. 80, 87-88 (1943);
Bachrodt Chevrolet Co. v. NLRB, 411 U.S. — (1973); Denham v.
NLRB, 411 U.S. ——— (1973).
No. 72–6303. Model Cities Policy Board of Ann Arbor et al.,
petitioners, v. James T. Lynn, Secretary of Housing and Urban De-
velopment, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals to
consider the question of mootness.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1111. Friends of the Earth et al., applicants, v. Ellis L.
Armstrong, Commissioner, Bureau of Reclamation, et al. The applica-
tion to vacate the stay order of the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit, dated May 1, 1973, presented to Mr. Justice
White and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 71-1332. San Antonio Independent School District et al.,
appellants, v. Demetrio P. Rodriguez et al. The motions of respond-
ents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis, nunc pro tunc and to
retax costs are denied.
No. 72-1441. Joseph Phillips, petitioner, v. United States. The
application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION POSTPONED
No. 72-1297. Donald E. Johnson, Administrator of Veterans'
Affairs et al., appellants, v. William Robert Robison, etc. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts. In
this case further consideration of the question of jurisdiction post-
poned to the hearing of the case on the merits. Case set for oral argu-
ment with No. 72–700.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 72–1328. United States, petitioner, v. Irving Kahn and Minnie
Kahn. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
No. 72–700. Henry Hernandez et al., petitioners, v. Veterans'
Administration et al. Motion to dispense with printing petition and
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted. Case set for oral argument with
No. 72-1297.

No. 72-6327. Carl Dean Knox, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

OPINIONS
No. 71-1225. John R. Gagnon, Warden, petitioner, v. Gerald H.
Scarpelli. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in
part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell. Statement by Mr. Justice Douglas dissenting in part.
No. 72-490. McDonnell Douglas Corporation, petitioner, v. Percy
Green. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 71-1178. Gulf States Utilities Company, petitioner, v. Federal
Power Commission et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join.
No. 72-10. David Moor et al., petitioners, v. County of Alameda
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern
District of California for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

MONDAY, MAY 14, 1973
595
No. 71-1647. Federal Maritime Commission, petitioner, v. Sea-
train Lines, Inc., et al. On the writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 72-624. United States, petitioner, v. Pennsylvania Industrial
Chemical Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment modified and, as
modified, remanded to the United States District Court for the West-
ern District of Pennsylvania for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. State-
ment by Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Jus-
tice Powell dissenting from Part I. Statement by Mr. Justice Black-
mun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissenting from the judgment and
Part II.
No. 71-1694. Sharron A. Frontiero and Joseph Frontiero, appel-
lants, v. Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Defense, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Middle District of
Alabama. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Alabama for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan anounced the judgment of this Court and delivered an opinion
in which Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice
Marshall join. Statement by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the
judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Jus-
tice Burger and Mr. Justice Blackman join, concurring in the judg-
ment. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 71–1637. City of Burbank et al., appellants, v. Lockheed Air
Terminal, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom
Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.
Adjourned until Monday, May 21, 1973, at 10 o'clock.
Х

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 21, 1973
596
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-42. I. I. Rosen, M. D., appellant, v. The Louisiana State
Board of Medical Examiners. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Louisiana for further consideration in light of Roe v. Wade,
410 U.S. 113 (1973) and Doe v. Bolton, 410 U.S. 179 (1973).
No. 72-1105. Stephens Truck Line, Inc., et al., appellants, v.
United States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Tennessee. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-1215. William Diamond et al., appellants, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. Motion to dispense with printing jurisdictional
statement granted. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 72-1313. Ronald Silverton, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-1342. David Kaplan et al., appellants, v. James B. Milli-
ken. Judge, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Western District of Kentucky. Judgment affirmed. For the reasons
stated in their dissent in Wells v. Edwards, No 72-621 of this term,
409 U.S. 1095 (1973), Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall
would note probable jurisdiction and give plenary consideration to
this case.
No. 72-6197. Clarence W. Shoemaker, appellant, v. Robert A.
Dwyer et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
510-278-73- -117

MONDAY, MAY 21, 1973
597
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-939. Fred Joiner et ux., et al., petitioners, v. City of
Dallas, Texas, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of Mitchum v. Foster,
407 U.S. 225 (1972); Lynch v. Household Finance Corporation, 405
U.S. 538 (1972); and Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37 (1971).
No. 72-498. Roy Tinder, petitioner, v. Virginia. It appearing
that petitioner, a defendant in a state criminal proceeding, died on
March 17, 1973, petition for a writ of certiorari to the Corporation
Court of Norfolk, Virginia, dismissed. Gersewitz v. New York, 326
U.S.687 (1945).
No. 72-6241. Joe Ben Webb, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Motion for leave to
file petition for writ of habeas corpus denied. Treating the papers
submitted as a petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit, certiorari granted. Upon the
representation of the Solicitor General as set forth in his memorandum
for the United States filed April 24, 1973, judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of the position presently asserted by the Government.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 61, Original. Quimet J. Petersen, plaintiff, v. Timoleon S. Spil-
iotopoulos, Individually and as Chancellor of the Consulate Royal of
Greece at New Orleans, Louisiana. The motion of the plaintiff for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The motion for leave
to file bill of complaint is denied.
No. A–1069. Alvin F. Applegate et al., applicants, v. New Jersey.
The application for stay of the judgment of the Appellate Division
of the Superior Court of New Jersey presented to Mr. Justice Douglas,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1118. John Miceli et al., applicants v. United States et al.
The application for stay of the mandate of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit presented to Mr. Justice Stewart,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
would grant the stay.
No. A-1123. Elisha Reid, Jr., applicant, v. Marquette University
et al. The application for stay of the mandate of the United States

MONDAY, MAY 21, 1973
598
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1136. Irving Greensphan, applicant, v. United States. The
application for recall of the mandate of the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit presented to Mr. Justice Douglas,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 72-586. Elmer O. Cady, Warden, petitioner, v. Chester J.
Dombrowski. The motion of the State of Florida for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, in support of the petitioner, after argument,
is granted.
No. 72–782. Gateway Coal Company, petitioner, v. United Mine
Workers of America et al. The motion of the National Association
of Manufacturers for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in support
of the petitioner, is granted.
No. 72-812. Thomas Tone Storer et al., appellants, v. Edmund
G. Brown, Jr., et al.; and
No. 72-6050. Laurence H. Frommhagen, appellant, v. Edmund
G. Brown, Jr., et al. The motion of appellants in No. 72-812 for
divided argument is granted, and it is ordered that Paul N. Halvonik,
Esquire, and Joseph Remcho, Esquire, be permitted to present oral
argument in the consolidated cases. The motion of appellant in No.
72-6050 to argue orally pro se is denied.
No. 72-822. The Renegotiation Board, petitioner, v. Bannercraft
Clothing Company, Inc., et al. The motion of the respondents to
permit two counsel to argue orally is granted.
No. 72-887. American Party of Texas et al., appellants, v. Mark
White, Jr., Secretary of State of Texas. The motion of appellant
Dunn for leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is granted
only to the extent that a typewritten brief may be filed.
No. 72-1148. Hoyt C. Cupp, Superintendent, Oregon State Peni-
tentiary, petitioner, v. Hugh Kyle Naughten. The motion of respond-
ent for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that
Ross R. Runkel, Esquire, of Salem, Oregon, a member of the Bar of
this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for
the respondent in this case.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 72–1254. Joseph Smith, Sheriff of Worcester County, appel-
lant, v. Valarie Goguen. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.

Reformatory, petitioner, v. Charles A. Tabasko, Jr. Motion to dispense
with printing petition and motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.

of the United States et al. Application for stay presented to Mr.
Justice Marshall, and by him referred to the Court, denied. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 72-1232. John Glendal Willis, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant
certiorari.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant cer-
tiorari.
No. 72–6201. Bruce G. Eldridge, petitioner, v. New York. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 72-6287. Charles Rosenthal, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant
certiorari.
No. 72-1331. Willie Allen et al., petitioners, v. City of Mobile
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
No. 72-1349. Helen L. Freeman, petitioner, v. Superior Court of
California, County of Alameda. Motion to dispense with printing
petition granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal
of Calfornia, First Appellate District, denied.

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur.

and Co. and William Thompson. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District, denied.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.

The Court will take a recess from today until Tuesday, May 29, 1973.

OPINIONS
No. 71-1607. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. The
Boeing Company et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Bur-
ger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Blackmun concur.

MONDAY, MAY 21, 1973
611
No. 71-6732. James Chaffin, petitioner, v. LeRoy Stynchcombe,
Sheriff of Fulton County. On writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan joins.
No. 71–1005. Michigan, petitioner, v. Leroy Payne. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Michigan. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Michigan for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall in Part III of which Mr.
Justice Stewart joins.
No. 72–630. Paul Hall, etc., et al., petitioners, v. John Cole. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist joins. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 71-1417. Booster Lodge No. 405, International Association of
Machinists and Aerospace Workers, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Na-
tional Labor Relations Board et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in
the judgment.
No. 72-549. School Board of the City of Richmond, Virginia, et al.,
petitioners, v. State Board of Education of the Commonwealth of
Virginia et al.; and
No. 72-550. Carolyn Bradley et al., petitioners, v. State Board of
Education of the Commonwealth of Virginia et al. On writs of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
Adjourned until Tuesday, May 29, 1973, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1973
612
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–287. Alan D. Miller, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene of
the State of New York, et al., appellants, v. Luis Gomez et al.; and
No. 72-5272. Anthony De Mundo et al., appellants, v. Alan D.
Miller, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene of the State of New York,
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis in No. 72-287 granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72–1302. Joel Edelman, Director of Illinois Department of
Public Aid, appellant, v. Georgia Townsend et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
Motions of appellees Alexander and Hucher for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois
so that it may enter a fresh judgment from which a timely appeal may
be taken to the Court of Appeals.
No. 72-1338. Giant of Maryland, Inc., appellant, v. State's At-
torney for Prince George's County, Maryland. Appeal from the Court
of Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 72-1365. Lillian B. A., appellant, v. Arthur O. S. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72–6506. Tyler Smith, appellant, v. California. Appeal from
the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-5924. Andrew King, appellant, v. West Virginia. Appeal
from the Circuit Court of West Virginia, Marion County. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
510-278-73-119

TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1973
613
No. 72-6412. Jimmie Quinn, Jr., appellant, v. United States.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jursidiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-6047. Raymond Ross Laursen, appellant, v. California.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction, and set
the case for oral argument.
No. 72-6344. Katherine Bell et al., appellants, v. Richard W.
Heim, Executive Director, New Mexico Health and Social Services.
Department, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of New Mexico. Judgment affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-780. California Adult Authority et al., petitioners, v. Jesse
Lee Griffin et al.; and
No. 72-5770. Charles G. M'Clary, petitioner, v. California Adult
Authority et al. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondents
in No. 72-780 and motion of petitioner in No. 72-5770 for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari
granted, judgments vacated and cases remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further consideration in light of Gagnon v. Scarpelli, 411
U.S. (1973).
_
No. 72-5398. Robert Newton Gardner, Jr., petitioner, v. D. J.
McCarthy, Superintendent, CMC-East Facility, San Luis Obispo,
California. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of Gagnon v. Scarpelli, 411 U.S. (1973).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1137. Dudley Darrington Smith, applicant, v. Texas. The
application for a stay of the mandate of the Court of Criminal Ap-
peals of Texas, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1164. Carl L. Marburger, State Commissioner of Education
of New Jersey, et al., applicants, v. Public Funds for Public Schools
of New Jersey et al. The application for a stay of the preliminary

,
TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1973
614
injunction ordered by the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of New Jersey presented to Mr. Justice Brennan, and by him
referred to the Court, is granted pending further order of this Court.
No. A-1173. L. G. Ruderer, applicant, v. United States, etc.;
United States through U.S. Army Judge Advocate General; Henry
S. Wise; and Morris Dittman. The applications for immediate equi-
table and all other relief presented to Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and by
him referred to the Court, are denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of these applications.
No. 72–782. Gateway Coal Company, petitioner, v. United Mine
Workers of America et al. The motion of the Chamber of Commerce
of the United States for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in sup-
port of the petitioner is granted.
No. 72-1118. Howard Phillips, Acting Director, Office of Eco-
nomic Opportunity, et al., appellants, v. Wayne Kennedy, etc., et al.
The motion of Michael Kaye for leave to intervene and to file a brief
on the merits is denied.
No. 72-6773. Kathleen Shaver, petitioner, v. Sharon Sandell et al.
The motion of the petitioner to expedite is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 72-1180. Old Dominion Branch No. 496, National Associa
tion of Letter Carriers, AFL-CIO, et al., appellants, v. Henry M.
Austin et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. In this case
probable jurisdiction noted and case set for oral argument in tandem
with No. 72-617.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit granted.

OPINIONS
Erwin N.
Griswold.
No. 71–1698. United States, petitioner, v. Cecil J. Bishop. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting statement by Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas.
No. 71-6356. John Doe et al., petitioners, v. John L. McMillan
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed in part and af-
firmed in part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Concur-
ring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in part and dissenting in

TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1973
627
part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dis-
senting in part, with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring in part and dissenting in part,
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Blackmun join,
and with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins as to Part 1.
No. 71-732. Merle R. Schneckloth, Superintendent, California
Conservation Center, petitioner, v. Robert Clyde Bustamonte. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 72-212. Hoyt C. Cupp, Superintendent, Oregon State Peni-
tentiary, petitioner, v. Daniel P. Murphy. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice White. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan dissent-
ing in part.
No. 72-5323. Francis A. Keeble, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join.
No. 71-863. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., petitioner, v.
Democratic National Committee;
No. 71-864. Federal Communications Commission et al., peti-
tioners, Business Executives' Move for Vietnam Peace et al.;
No. -865. Post-Newsweek Stations, Capital Area, Inc., peti-
tioner, Business Executives' Move for Vietnam Peace; and
No.
866. American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., petitioner,
v. Democratic National Committee. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1973
628
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the judgment of this Court.
Mr. Chief Justice Burger announced the judgment of this Court
and delivered an opinion with respect to Parts I, II, and IV, in
which Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join, and with respect to Parts I, II, and
III, in which Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in Parts I, II, and III.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in Parts I, II, and IV.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in Parts I, II, and IV,
with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall concurs.
Adjourned until Monday, June 4, 1973, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1973
629
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Powell.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 72-1164. Deborah A. Northcross et al., petitioners, v. Board of
Education of the Memphis City Schools et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated insofar as it
relates to the denial of costs and attorneys' fees, and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Marshall took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 72–6198. James R. Douglas, petitioner, v. William E. Buder,
Judge. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Missouri. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of Missouri for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Chief
Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist concur in the result. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-745. Ada Biffar Ryan, etc., appellant, v. Elizabeth Linda
Klein et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of New York. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-770. Commissioner of Social Services of the State of New
York et al., appellants. v. Elizabeth Linda Klein et al.; and
No. 72-803. Nassau County Medical Center et al., appellants, v.
Elizabeth Linda Klein et al. Appeals from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of New York. Judgment vacated and
cases remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of New York for further consideration in light of Roe v.
Wade, 410 U.S. 113 (1973), and Doe v. Bolton, 410 U.S. 179 (1973).
510-278-73--122

MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1973
630
No. 72-943. Dean Fisher et al., appellants, v. Martin Graves et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Maine. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-1408. Robert B. Carleson, Director, California State De-
partment of Social Welfare, appellant, v. Joyce Yee-Litt et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
California. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-1178. J. G. Stein, etc., appellant, v. Michael J. Howlett,
Auditor of Public Accounts of Illinois, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 72-1413. Leo Itz et ux., appellants, v. Vernon E. Penick,
President, Fredericksburg Independent School District, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-1447. James Edwin Blackburn, appellant, v. Indiana.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-1251. Standard Oil Company of California, appellant, v.
United States. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice White
took no part in the consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 72-1406. Kenneth Oldroyd et al., appellants, v. George F.
Kugler, Jr., Attorney General and Chief Prosecutor of New Jersey,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District.
of New Jersey. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 72-1415. William Richter et ux., appellants, v. Commissioner
of Internal Revenue. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-6221. Geneva H. Sayles, appellant, v. Albert Mirman &
Associates, Inc. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Ap-
peals. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-6293. Mickey Gemmill et al., appellants, v. California.
Appeal from the Superior Court of California, County of Shasta. The

MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1973
631
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1124. Daniel Edward Henry et al., applicants, v. John E.
Warner, Individually and in his capacity as Secretary of Navy, et al.
The application for an order to vacate in part the order of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, dated May 8, 1973,
presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court,
is denied.
No. 71–1255. United States, petitioner, v. Charles J. Ash, Jr. The
motion of the respondent for leave to file a supplemental brief, after
argument, is granted.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 72-6156. Mallie Lewis, appellant, v. City of New Orleans.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted.

No. 72-1108. Mobil Oil Corporation, petitioner, v. Federal Power
Commission. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 72-1169. Environmental Defense Fund, Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. Corps of Engineers of United States Army et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the North Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant
certiorari.

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.

Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would
grant certiorari.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals

636
for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant
certiorari.

petition.

and United Transportation Union, petitioners, v. Robert Rock et al.

the consideration or decision of this petition.

OPINIONS
641
No. 72-90. United States, petitioner, v. Chicago, Burlington &
Quincy Railroad Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Claims. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States Court of Claims for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 72-350. United States, appellant, v. State Tax Commission of
Mississippi et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Southern District of Mississippi. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Mississippi for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurs.

MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1973
642
No. 72–654. United States, petitioner, v. Archie L. Mason et al.,
and
No. 72–606. Oklahoma, petitioner, v. Archie L. Mason and Mar-
garet R. Mason, etc., et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Claims. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the United
States Court of Claims for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice
Douglas concurs in the result.
Adjourned until Monday, June 11, 1973, at 10 o'clock.

FRIDAY, JUNE 8, 1973

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1219. Edwin H. Helfant, applicant, v. George F. Kugler,
Attorney General of New Jersey, et al. The application for an injunc-
tion pending disposition of appeal in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit presented to Mr. Justice Brennan,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Brennan took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1973
644
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Mr. Justice Douglas said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 72-1310. Sam Dean, petitioner, v. The Gadsden Times Pub-
lishing Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of
Civil Appeals of Alabama. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Court of Civil Appeals
of Alabama for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-1327. REA Express, Inc., appellant, v. Alabama Great
Southern Railroad Company et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of New York. Judgment
affirmed. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this appeal.
No. 72-1405. Moses Lake School District No. 161 et al., appellants,
v. Big Bend Community College, District No. 18, et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 72–1438. Kenneth Michael Smith, appellant, v. Virginia.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72–6611. Katherine Ander, appellant, v. Saul Ander. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72–1594. William Diamond et al., appellants, v. United States
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. Motion to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement
granted. Judgment affirmed. Motion for an injunction denied. Mr.
510-278-73-125

MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1973
645
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
appeal and these motions.
No. 72-6350. Irvin H. Mason, appellant, v. Panama Canal Com-
pany. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the
denial of the petition believing that the case is not moot, and would
vacate judgment and remand cause to the trial court for resolution
of respondent's counterclaim.
No. 72-6725. Dorothy D. Ross et al., appellants, v. Brown Title
Corporation et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas dissents from the affirmance.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-1245. A. E. Slayton, Jr., Superintendent, Virginia State
Penitentiary, petitioner, v. James C. Hammer. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of Michigan v. Payne, 412 U.S. — (1973); and Chaffin v. Stynch-
combe, 412 U.S. (1973). Mr. Justice Douglas would affirm judg-
ment. See Michigan v. Payne, 412 U.S. - (1973); Chaffin v. Stynch-
combe, 412 U.S. (1973); and Moon v. Maryland, 398 U.S. 319, 321
(1970) (dissenting opinions).
-
-
-
No. 71-1281. Martha K. Linder, Warden, petitioner, v. Helen
Jones Recor. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Chaffin v. Stynchcombe, 412
U.S. (1973). Mr. Justice Douglas would affirm judgment. See
Chaffin v. Stynchcombe, 412 U.S. (1973); and Moon v. Maryland,
398 U.S. 319, 321 (1970) (dissenting opinions).

No. D-10. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Frank G. Kirtz. It
is ordered that Frank G. Kirtz, of St. Louis, Missouri, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue return-
able within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not
be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. A-1034. L. G. Ruderer, applicant, v. Lyndon B. Johnson. The
application for equitable relief by injunction and enforcement of
orders, etc., is denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this application.
No. 35, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Maine et al. The motion of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts for
a preliminary injunction is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant
the preliminary injunction.

OPINIONS
Charles McCurdy
Mathias, Jr.
No. 72-658. City of Kenosha, Wisconsin, et al., appellants, v. Peter
G. Bruno et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Wisconsin. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Wisconsin for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas dissenting in part.
No. 72–656. Orval C. Logue et al., petitioners, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for consideration of the liability of the Government insofar
as that liability may be based on the negligence of Deputy Marshal
Bowers. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Statement by Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall.

MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1973
661
No. 71-1182. Raymond Mattz, petitioner, v. G. Raymond Arnett,
etc. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First
Appellate District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District, for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 71-6042. Ronald Dale Wardius, petitioner, v. Oregon. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oregon. Judgment reversed
OF APPRICS
and case remanded to the m Court of Oregon for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurs in the result.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in the result.
No. 72–493. John W. Vlandis, Director of Admissions, The Uni-
versity of Connecticut, appellant, v. Margaret Marsh Kline and
Patricia Catapano. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Connecticut. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring
in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger
with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas join.
No. 72-5521. Clarence Eugene Strunk, petitioner, v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger announced
by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 59, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. States of
Nevada and California. On motion for leave to file bill of complaint.
Motion for leave file bill of complaint denied, but without prejudice
to refiling it should the posture of the litigation change in a manner
that presents a more substantial basis for the exercise of the Court's
original jurisdiction. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
No. 72-804. Robert W. Fri, Acting Administrator of the Environ-
mental Protection Agency, petitioner, v. Sierra Club et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, June 18, 1973, at 10 o'clock.
