(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 13, 1973
661 A
Supreme Court of the United States
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1221. Samuel Shapiro, applicant, v. Thomas E. Ferrandina,
United States Marshal for the Southern District of New York. The
application for a stay of the mandate of the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit presented to Mr. Justice Marshall,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would
grant the application.
No. 72–1173. International Business Machine Corporation, appel-
lant, v. United States. The application for a stay of the execution and
enforcement of the pre-trial order No. 5 of the United States District
Court for the Southern District of New York and for a stay of the
mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
presented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by him referred to the Court, is
denied. Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this appli-
cation. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant the application.

MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1973
662
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–635. Kenneth Glusman and Anthony B. Lamb, appellants,
v. The Board of Trustees of the University of North Carolina. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of North Carolina for further
consideration in light of Vlandis v. Kline et al. 412 U.S.
Mr. Justice Douglas would affirm judgment.
(1973).
No. 72-1259. Abraham Teitelbaum, appellant, v. California. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate Dis-
trict. Motion to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement
granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-1565. United States, appellant, v. Trans Texas Bancorpo-
ration, Inc. et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Western District of Texas. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall would note probable
jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 72-6329. William K. McAllister, appellant, v. Virginia. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-6385. Howard Allen Logan, appellant, v. Western Union
Telegraph Company, etc. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of New York. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.

CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
663
No. 72-6012. Virgil A. Kelsaw, Jr., petitioner, v. Oregon. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Oregon. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals of Oregon for further consideration in light of Wardiys v.
Oregon, 412 U.S.- (1973). Mr. Justice Douglas would grant peti-
tion for certiorari and reverse judgment for reasons set forth in his
separate opinion in Wardius v. Oregon, 412 U.S.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
(1973).
No. A-1079. James Ben Johnson, applicant, v. Missouri. The appli-
cation for bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1186. Joseph Waller, Jr., applicant, v. Florida. The appli-
cation for a stay of the execution and enforcement of the judgment
of conviction in the Circuit Court of Pinellas County, Florida, pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Powell, and by him referred to the Court, is
granted pending further order of this Court.
No. 72-1035. Julia Rogers, petitioner, v. Leroy Loether et al. The
motion of respondents for leave to proceed further herein in forma
pauperis or in the alternative to submit respondents' brief in type-
written form is denied.
No. 72-1086. DeLong Corporation et al., petitioners, v. Oregon by
and through its State Highway Commission. The motion of the re-
spondent for allowance of attorney's fees is denied.
No. 72-1264. Mayor of the City of Philadelphia et al., petitioners,
v. Educational Equality League et al. The motion of respondents
for leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 72-1355. United States, petitioner, v. William Earl Mattlock.
The motion of the respondent for appointment of counsel is granted,
and it is ordered that Donald S. Eisenberg, Esquire, of Madison,
Wisconsin, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for
the respondent in this case.

No. 72-5443. James Edward Barnes, petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.

MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1973
674
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
No. 72-214. The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Com-
pany et al., appellants, v. The Wichita Board of Trade et al.; and
No. 72-433. Interstate Commerce Commission, appellant, v..
Wichita Board of Trade. Appeals from the United States District for
the District of Kansas. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in
part and cases remanded to the United States District for the District
of Kansas for further proceedings in conformity with the judgment.
of this Court. Mr. Justice Marshall announced the judgment of the
Court, and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White, concurring in part and dissenting in part, with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.

the United States District for the District of Connecticut for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by

part and dissenting in part, with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Marshall join, in this case and in No. 72-147, post.

District of Texas for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-

ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTIONS
Applicant
City and State
Movant
John Hendrik Germeraad
Bowie, Md.
Gene Alan Erl
Medford, Wis.
Solicitor General
Erwin N. Griswold.
Solicitor General
Erwin N. Griswold.
Joel Dennis Frederick
Salt Lake City,
Utah.
Frank E. Moss.
James H. Berkson
Washington, D.C. Stanley I.
Westreich.
Mr. Solicitor General Griswold presented the Honorable Elliot L.
Richardson, Attorney General of the United States.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Attorney General, the Court welcomes you to the performance
of the important duties which devolve upon you as the chief law officer
of the Government, and as an officer of this Court. Your commission
will be recorded with the Clerk."
The Chief Justice said:
"The Court takes note that Solicitor General Griswold today makes
his final appearance as the incumbent of that high office. He has served
with distinction for nearly six years, one of the longest tenures since
the office of Solicitor General was created more than 100 years ago.
"On behalf of the Court, I wish to thank him for his services to the
Court and wish him well in the years ahead. We include Mrs. Griswold
in our good wishes for the future."

OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 72-1396. Donald W. Fausner et ux., petitioners, v. Commis-
sioner of Internal Revenue. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ
of certiorari granted, and judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam.
Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari and set case for oral
argument.

et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Ohio. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District for the Northern District of Ohio for further considera-
tion in light of Miller v. California,

vacate the judgment and remand case for further proceedings not in-
consistent with his dissent in Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, ante.
See Miller v. California, ante (dissenting opinion of Justice Brennan).
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this appeal.
No. 70-10. Florida ex rel. Robert L. Shevin, Attorney General of
Florida, et al., appellants, v. M & W Theatres, Inc., et al. Appeal from

et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

MILLER V. CALIFORNIA, ANTE
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1164. Carl L. Marburger et al., applicants, v. Public Funds
for Public Schools of New Jersey et al. The application for stay of
injunction heretofore granted by this Court on May 29, 1973, is
vacated. For the reasons stated in the dissenting opinions in Nos.
72–694, 72–753, 72–791, and 72-929, Committee for Public Education
v. Nyquist, and Nos. 72-459 and 72-620, Sloan v. Lemon, the Chief
Justice, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Rehnquist dissent from the
vacation of the stay of District Court's preliminary injunction.
JUSTICE
No. A-1220. Glenn A. Leamer, applicant, v. Erskind DeRamus,
Superintendent, State Correctional Institution. The application for
bail is denied.
No. A-1234. Aberdeen and Rockfish Railroad Company et al.,
applicants, v. Students Challenging Regulatory Agency Procedures
(SCRAP) et al.; and
No. A-1239. Interstate Commerce Commission, applicant, v. Stu-
dents Challenging Regulatory Agency Procedures (SCRAP) et al.
The application of SCRAP et al. to vacate the stay entered by the
Chief Justice is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would vacate the stay.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.
The motion of the State of Louisiana to enlarge the reference to the
Special Master to fix the extension of Louisiana's island boundary into
the Gulf of Mexico between Louisiana, Texas and the United States to
the extent of Louisiana's title under the Submerged Lands Act, or other
alternative relief, is referred to the Special Master. The Solicitor Gen-
eral is invited to file a brief expressing the views of the United States.

MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1973
710
In due course, after receipt of the brief of the United States, the Spe-
cial Master shall submit his report to the Court on the motion.
No. 64, Original. State of New Hampshire, plaintiff, v. State of
Maine. The motion for a preliminary injunction is denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant the motion condi-
tioned upon the imposition upon all fishermen operating in the dis-
puted area of the more onerous of the conditions presently imposed
by either New Hampshire or Maine.
No. 72-955. W. C. Spomer, State's Attorney of Alexander County,
Illinois, petitioner, v. Ezell Littleton et al. The motion of the Attorney
General of California for leave to participate in oral argument, as
amicus curiae, and for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 72-1513. Con F. Shea, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Ascension
Vialpando, etc. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 72-1613. Lawrence S. Huffman et al., petitioners, v. United
States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, et al. The
application for stay or writ of injunction presented to Mr. Justice
Stewart, and by him referred to the Court, and the motion to advance
are denied. The motion of Pursue, Ltd. to participate as a party
respondent is granted.
No. 72-1712. In re Grand Jury Subpoena Served Upon Simon
Horowitz. The application for stay presented to Mr. Justice Marshall,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and
Mr. Justice Brennan would grant the application.
No. 72-6871. Robert Lee Bell, petitioner, v. United States. The
application for stay presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 72-6900. Jane Doe etc., appellant, v. Planned Parenthood
Association of Utah. The application for stay presented to Mr. Justice.
Brennan, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

argument in tandem with No. 72-1318.

713
No. 72-5375. Angel Gebbia Marquez, Jr., petitioner, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would
grant certiorari.
No. 72-5998. Leroy Peter Coleman, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of
Appeals denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 72-6377. Thomas Gregg Holt, petitioner, v. California. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First
Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 72-385. Tate Educational Foundation, Inc., petitioner, v.
Kelly McNeal et al. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 72-835. John M. Pettibone, Director, Division of Parole and
Probation, Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional
Services, petitioner, v. Kenneth Woodall. Motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
denied.
No. 72–1187. M. Browning Combs et al., petitioners, v. Princess
Ranola Johnson et al. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 72-1473. United States, petitioner, v. Edmund Herman Roth-
felder. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 72–1474. United States, petitioner, v. Allan Ray King. Motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 72-649. Corpus Christi Independent School District et al.,
petitioners, v. Jose Cisneros et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. The
Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Blackmun, and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist, feeling that no useful purpose is to be served by
setting the case for oral argument, would nevertheless grant the peti-
tion, vacate judgment and remand case to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Keyes v. School District No. 1, U.S. ——— (1973).
-
-

MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1973
714
No. 72-739. The Board of Education of the Little Rock School
District et al., petitioners, v. Delores Clark et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.
No. 72-5348. Lealon Cooley, etc., petitioner, v. Strickland Trans-
portation Co., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
would grant certiorari and reverse judgment.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 71-1664. Martin W. Essex et al., appellants, v. Benson A.
Wolman et al. Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied.
No.72-146. Bill R. Hunter, dba The Courier, petitioner, v. United
States. Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied. Mr..
Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun would
grant the motion.

The Chief Justice announced the following order of the Court:
"All cases submitted and all business before the Court at this term
in readiness for disposition having been disposed of,
"It is ordered by this Court that all cases on the docket be, and they
are hereby, continued to the next term."
Adjourned to the time and place appointed by law.
